revision.comment: /* List of Blue Planet Prize Laureates */
revision.text:
The '''[http://www.af-info.or.jp/en/blueplanet/about.html Blue Planet Prize]''' recognises outstanding efforts in scientific research or applications of science that contribute to solving global environmental problems. The prize was created by the [[Asahi Glass Co.|Asahi Glass Foundation]] in 1992, the year of the [[Rio Earth Summit]], and since then the foundation has awarded the prize to two winners every year.<ref>http://www.af-info.or.jp/en/blueplanet/list.html</ref> In 2012, twenty of the Blue Planet Prize winners collaborated on a [https://www.scribd.com/doc/82268857/Blue-Planet-Synthesis-Paper-for-UNEP joint paper] that was launched at the [[UN Environment Programme]]'s Governing Council meeting in [[Nairobi]] on 20 February.<ref>UNEP. 2012. [http://www.unep.org/newscentre/Default.aspx?DocumentID=2667&ArticleID=9026&l=en Blue Planet Prize winners call for transformational change to achieve sustainable development]. Press release. 10 February 2011.</ref><ref>Pearce. F. 2012. [https://www.newscientist.com/article/dn21465-earth-summit-is-doomed-to-fail-say-leading-ecologists.html Earth Summit is doomed to fail, say leading ecologists]. New Scientist website. 10 February 2012.</ref>
==List of laureates== * 1992 [[Syukuro Manabe|Dr. Syukuro Manabe]] and the [[International Institute for Environment and Development]] * 1993 [[Charles Keeling|Dr Charles D. Keeling]] and [[IUCN-The World Conservation Union]] * 1994 Prof. Dr. [[:de:Eugen Seibold|Eugen Seibold]] and [[Lester R. Brown|Mr. Lester R. Brown]] * 1995 [[Maurice F. Strong|Mr. Maurice F. Strong]] and [[Bert Bolin|Dr. Bert Bolin]] * 1996 [[Wallace S. Broecker|Dr. Wallace S. Broecker]] and [[MS Swaminathan Research Foundation|M.S. Swaminathan Research Foundation]] * 1997 [[James Lovelock|Dr. James E. Lovelock]] and [[Conservation International]] * 1998 [[Mikhail Budyko|Prof. Mikhail I. Budyko]] and [[David R. Brower|Mr. David R. Brower]] * 1999 [[Paul R. Ehrlich|Dr. Paul R. Ehrlich]] and Prof. Qu Geping * 2000 [[Theo Colborn|Dr. Theo Colborn]] and [[Karl-Henrik Robèrt|Dr. Karl-Henrik Robèrt]] * 2001 [[Lord May of Oxford|Lord (Robert) May of Oxford]] and [[Norman Myers|Dr. Norman Myers]] * 2002 [[Harold A. Mooney|Professor Harold A. Mooney]] and [[Gustave Speth|Prof. J. Gustave Speth]] * 2003 [[Gene E. Likens|Dr. Gene E. Likens]] / [[F. Herbert Bormann|Dr. F. Herbert Bormann]] and [[Vo Quy|Dr. Vo Quy]] * 2004 [[Susan Solomon|Dr. Susan Solomon]] and [[Gro Harlem Brundtland|Dr. Gro Harlem Brundtland]] * 2005 [[Nicholas Shackleton|Prof. Sir Nicholas Shackleton]] and [[Gordon H. Sato|Dr. Gordon Hisashi Sato]] * 2006 [[Akira Miyawaki|Dr. Akira Miyawaki]] and [[Emil Salim|Dr. Emil Salim]] * 2007 Professor Joseph L. Sax and [[Amory B. Lovins|Dr. Amory B. Lovins]] * 2008 [[Claude Lorius|Dr. Claude Lorius]] and [[José Goldemberg|Professor José Goldemberg]] * 2009 [[Hirofumi Uzawa|Professor Hirofumi Uzawa]] and [[Lord Stern of Brentford|Lord (Nicholas) Stern of Brentford]] * 2010 [[James Hansen|Dr. James Hansen]] and [[Robert Watson (scientist)|Dr. Robert Watson]] * 2011 [[Jane Lubchenco|Dr. Jane Lubchenco]] and [[Barefoot College]] * 2012 [[William E. Rees|Professor William E. Rees]] / [[Mathis Wackernagel|Dr. Mathis Wackernagel]] and [[Thomas E. Lovejoy|Dr. Thomas E. Lovejoy]] * 2013 Dr. Taroh Matsuno and Dr. [[Daniel Sperling]] * 2014 [[Herman Daly|Prof. Herman Daly]] and [[Daniel H. Janzen|Prof.Daniel H. Janzen]] / [[Instituto Nacional de Biodiversidad]] (INBio) * 2015 [[Partha Dasgupta|Professor Sir Partha Dasgupta FBA FRS]] and [[Jeffrey D. Sachs|Professor Jeffrey D. Sachs]] * 2016 Mr. [[Pavan Sukhdev]] and Prof. Markus Borner * 2017 Prof. [[Hans Joachim Schellnhuber]] and Prof. [[Gretchen C. Daily]] * 2018 Prof. [[Brian Walker (ecologist)|Brian Walker]] and Prof. [[Malin Falkenmark]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox company | name = Bob Barker Company | logo = Bob_Barker_Company_logo.png | type = | industry = [[Corrections]] | fate = | predecessor = <!-- or: | predecessors = --> | successor = <!-- or: | successors = --> | founded = {{Start date and age|1972}} in [[North Carolina]], [[United States]] | founder = Robert Barker Sr. | defunct = <!-- {{End date|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | hq_location_city = [[Fuquay-Varina, North Carolina]] | hq_location_country = [[United States]] | area_served = <!-- or: | areas_served = --> | key_people = {{ubl| Robert Barker Sr. ([[Chief executive officer|CEO]])| Robert Barker Jr. (President)| Nancy Barker Johns (Executive Vice President)| Tim Workman (Vice President of Logistics)}} | products = bedding, clothing, food service, footwear, laundry, personal care, recreation, security, medical supplies | owner = <!-- or: | owners = --> | num_employees = | num_employees_year = <!-- Year of num_employees data (if known) --> | parent = | website = <!-- {{URL|example.com}} --> }}
'''Bob Barker Company, Inc.''' is an American company that sells supplies to [[Prison|prisons]]. The company was founded in 1972, with headquarters in [[Fuquay-Varina, North Carolina]], and a distribution and sales center in [[Ogden, Utah]].<ref name="bloomberg">{{cite web |title=Company Overview of Bob Barker Company, Inc. |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/private/snapshot.asp?privcapId=4372192 |website=Bloomberg |accessdate=26 July 2018}}</ref> Its products include prisoner and officer uniforms, bedding, toiletries, cleaning supplies and security and restraint equipment.<ref>{{cite web |title=Products : Jail and Correctional Supplies |url=https://www.bobbarker.com/products.html |website=www.bobbarker.com |accessdate=26 July 2018 |language=en}}</ref>
== History == According to the company's website, founder Bob Barker, a former newspaper editor from [[North Carolina]], initially started the company selling supplies and equipment to restaurants. The company began supplying to jails and prisons in the southeastern United States in the early 1980s.<ref>{{cite web |title=History |url=https://www.bobbarker.com/history |website=www.bobbarker.com |accessdate=26 July 2018 |language=en}}</ref>
Since 1995, the company has been awarded at least $13 million in federal prison system contracts in the United States, representing about 100 federal prisons across the country.<ref name="truthout">{{cite web |title=Prison Supply Chains Reveal Some Surprises |url=https://truthout.org/articles/is-orange-the-new-green/ |website=Truthout |accessdate=26 July 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=FPDS-NG ezSearch |url=https://www.fpds.gov/ezsearch/fpdsportal?s=FPDSNG.COM&q=Bob+Barker+GLOBAL_VENDOR_NAME%3A%22BOB+BARKER+COMPANY++INC.%22%20%20AGENCY_NAME%3A%22Federal%20Prison%20System%22&indexName=awardfull&templateName=1.4.4 |website=www.fpds.gov |accessdate=26 July 2018}}</ref> In 2016, the company began a $4.15 million distribution center expansion in Fuquay-Varina.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Gargan |first1=Henry |title=Detention supplier Bob Barker Co. plans $4.15M expansion of Fuquay-Varina facility |url=https://www.newsobserver.com/news/local/community/southwest-wake-news/article116652023.html |accessdate=26 July 2018 |work=News & Observer |date=November 23, 2016 |language=en}}</ref>
A 2008 report by SweatFree Communities, a campaign of the [[International Labor Rights Forum]], alleged use of [[Bangladesh]]-based [[sweatshop]] labor by the company.<ref>{{cite web |title=Subsidizing Sweatshops Factsheet for New Jersey |url=http://www.sweatfree.org/docs/SubsidizingSweatshops_NewJersey.pdf |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151102063237/http://www.sweatfree.org/docs/SubsidizingSweatshops_NewJersey.pdf |archivedate=2 November 2015}}</ref> Company president Robert Barker Jr. responded by stating the company only worked with suppliers that "share our commitment to the health and safety of those working in this industry."<ref>{{cite news |last1=Anderson |first1=Lynn |title=Group alleges labor abuse -- baltimoresun.com |url=http://www.baltimoresun.com/news/local/bal-md.sweatshop03jul03,0,6450297.story |work=Baltimore Sun |date=July 3, 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080905051318/http://www.baltimoresun.com/news/local/bal-md.sweatshop03jul03,0,6450297.story |archivedate=5 September 2008}}</ref>
In 2009, the company founded the philanthropic Bob Barker Company Foundation, with a focus on reducing [[recidivism]].<ref name="truthout"/><ref>{{cite web |title=History |url=http://www.bobbarkercompanyfoundation.org/history/ |website=Bob Barker Company Foundation |accessdate=26 July 2018 |date=10 November 2013}}</ref>
While prison lore has suggested that the company is affiliated with game show host [[Bob Barker]], there is no relationship between the two.<ref>{{cite web |title=FACT CHECK: Bob Barker Prison Toiletries |url=https://www.snopes.com/fact-check/pa-barker/ |website=Snopes.com |accessdate=26 July 2018}}</ref>
== References == {{reflist}}
== External links == * [https://www.bobbarker.com/ Official website]
