revision.text:
{{Redirect|Prince of the blood|the novel by Raymond E. Feist|Prince of the Blood (novel)}} {{Italic title|reason=[[:Category:French words and phrases]].}} [[File:Crown of a Prince of the Blood of France (variant).svg|thumb|right|250px|[[Heraldic crown]] of a ''prince du sang'']]
A '''''prince du sang''''' ({{IPA-fr|pʁɛ̃s dy sɑ̃}}, Prince of the Blood) is a person legitimately descended in [[dynasty#dynasts|dynastic]] line from any of a [[realm]]'s [[hereditary monarchy|hereditary monarchs]]. Historically, the term has been used to refer to men and women descended in the [[patrilineality|male line]] from a sovereign, although as [[primogeniture#absolute primogeniture|absolute primogeniture]] has become more common in monarchies, those with succession rights through female descent are more likely than in the past to be accorded the princely title (e.g., [[Monarchy of Belgium#Members of the Belgian Royal Family|Belgian Royal Family]]).
In some European kingdoms, especially France, this appellation was a specific rank in its own right, of a more restricted use than other titles.
==History== Under the [[House of Capet]], the monarchy was feudal, and the younger sons and grandsons of kings did not have rights or precedence based on their royal descent. Feudal titles determined rank. Under Philip Augustus, the Duke of Burgundy, a peer of France, could be reckoned to be mightier than the Count of Dreux, a "baron of the second rank", even though the latter is a paternal cousin of the king, while the former was only a distant [[agnate]]. In the feudal era, the agnates of the king held no special status. This was because agnatic primogeniture had not yet received its sanction as the law governing the succession to the French throne.
Following the [[House of Valois|Valoi]]s succession, the agnates of the king, being "capable of the crown", rose in prominence. New peerages were created for the king's agnates, and for a long time this continued to be so, before the peerage was extended to non-royalty. Over time, the dignity of a peer, which is feudal in nature, and the dignity of a prince of the blood, which is dynastic in nature, clashed. Non-royal peers and princes of the blood who were peers constantly disputed for higher precedence than the other. As the royal line contracted, each prince of the blood gained greater prominence. Finally, in 1576, [[Henry III of France]] issued an edict, as a counterpoise to the growing power of the [[House of Guise]], which made the princes of the blood supreme over the peerage, and amongst themselves, the closer in the line of succession would outrank the more distant, without regard to the actual title that they held.
==As a rank== In France, the rank of ''prince du sang'' was the highest held at [[court (royal)|court]] after the immediate family of the king during the ''[[Ancien Régime|ancien régime]]'' and the [[Bourbon Restoration]].<ref name="spanheim">{{cite book|last= Spanheim|first= Ézéchiel|authorlink=Ezekiel, Freiherr von Spanheim|editor= ed. Émile Bourgeois|title= Relation de la Cour de France|series= le Temps retrouvé|year = 1973|publisher=Mercure de France|location= [[Paris]]|language= French|pages= 70, 87, 313–314}}</ref> The rank of ''prince du sang'' or ''princesse du sang'' was restricted to legitimate [[patrilineality|agnates]] of the Capetian dynasty who were not members of the [[Fils de France|immediate family of the king]]. Originating in the 14th century, male ''princes du sang'' came to be recognized as entitled to seats on the ''[[Conseil du roi|Conseil du Roi]]'' and the ''[[Parlement of Paris|Parlement de Paris]]'', to precedence above all [[French peerage|peers]] and to precedence among each other according to their respective places in the [[order of succession]].
During the last century of the reign of the [[House of Valois]], when religious strife brought forth rivals for the throne, ''prince du sang'' became restricted in use to refer to dynasts who were distant members of the Royal Family (i.e., those who were not children or grandchildren in the male line of a French king and, as such, entitled to specific, higher rank of their own as ''enfants'' and ''petits-enfants de France'').<ref name="spanheim"/>
In theory, the princes of the blood included all members of the [[Capetian dynasty]]. In practice, only the agnatic descendants of [[Saint Louis IX]], such as the [[House of Valois|Valois]] and the [[House of Bourbon|Bourbons]], were acknowledged as ''princes du sang''.<ref name="spanheim"/> France's kings, for instance, refused to recognize the [[Capetian House of Courtenay|Courtenay]] Capetians as princes of the blood. The Courtenays descended in legitimate male-line from [[Louis VI of France|King Louis VI]], but had become impoverished, minor nobles over the centuries. Their repeated petitions for recognition to the Bourbon rulers were in vain. When the [[Treaty of Montmartre]] was concluded in 1662, declaring the [[House of Lorraine]] to be heirs to the French throne in the event of extinction of the Bourbons, the Courtenays protested, requesting substitution of the phrase "the royal house issued in legitimate male line from the kings of France" to no avail. In 1715 Louis-Charles de Courtenay, his son Charles-Roger and his brother Roger were once again rebuffed in their attempt to seek recognition of their status. Roger, ''abbé'' de Courtenay, was the last male of the family, dying on 5 May 1733, and his sister Hélène de Courtenay, marquise de Bauffremont (1689–20 June 1768), obtained no redress when she appealed to the king in 1737 after the [[Parlement of Paris]] ordered the term "princesse du sang royal de France" deleted from court documents.
Even a [[cadet branch]] of the Bourbon line, the Bourbon-Carencys, who were most distantly related to the [[Duke of Bourbon#Peerage|Dukes of Bourbon]], were denied princely rank and excluded from the ''Conseil du Roi'' until their extinction in 1530. They descended from [[List of lords and princes of Carency#House of Bourbon-Carency (14th–16th centuries)|Jean, seigneur de Carency]] (1378–1457), the youngest son of [[John I, Count of La Marche|Jean I de Bourbon, Count of La Marche]].
Since 1733, all legitimate male Capetians were of the House of Bourbon, of the Vendôme branch, descended from [[Charles, Duke of Vendôme]]. Charles' eldest son [[Antoine of Navarre|Antoine, King of Navarre]], was the ancestor of the royal dynasties of France and Spain, and of the [[House of Orléans]], while his youngest son [[Louis, Prince of Condé (1530–1569)]], was the ancestor of the [[Princes of Condé|House of Condé]]. A cadet branch of the Condés was the [[Princes of Conti|House of Conti]], who in male line descended of [[Henri, Prince of Condé (1588–1646)]].
In an edict of July 1714, Louis XIV declared his legitimized sons, the Duke of Maine and Count of Toulouse, to be ''princes du sang'' and accorded them rights of succession to the French throne following all other ''princes du sang''. Though the ''Parlement de Paris'' refused to register the decree, the king exercised his right to compel registration by conducting a ''[[lit de justice]]''. The edict was revoked and annulled on 18 August 1715 by the ''Parlement'' on the authority of the regent after the king's death. As a chancellor of Louis XIV had warned, a king could only make princes of the blood through his queen.<ref>The Institutions of France Under the Absolute Monarchy, 1598–1789, Volume 2, p.93</ref>
==Styles== Those who held this rank were usually styled by their main [[peerage of France|ducal peerage]], but sometimes other titles were used, indicating a more precise status than ''prince du sang''.
The most senior princes used specific styles such as ''monsieur le prince'' or ''monsieur le duc'', whereas the junior princes used the style ''[[monseigneur]]'' followed by their noble title, such as ''[[Antoine Philippe, Duke of Montpensier|monseigneur le duc de Montpensier]]''. The style [[Serene Highness]] (''altesse sérénissime'') was used in writing only.
==''Monsieur le Prince''== This was the style of the '''First Prince of the Blood''' ({{lang-fr|premier prince du sang}}), which normally belonged to the most senior (by [[primogeniture]]) male member of the royal dynasty who is neither a ''[[fils de France]]'' ("son of France", i.e. of the King or the [[Dauphin of France|Dauphin]]") nor a ''[[Fils de France#Petit-fils de France|petit-fils de France]]'' ("grandson of France", son of a ''fils de France''). In practice, it was not always clear who was entitled to the rank, and it often took a specific act of the king to make the determination.
The rank carried with it various privileges, including the right to a household paid out of state revenues. The rank was held for life: the birth of a new, more senior prince who qualified for the position did not deprive the current holder of his use of the style. The [[Prince de Condé|Princes of Condé]] used the style of ''Monsieur le Prince'' for over a century (1589–1709). The right to use the style passed to the [[House of Orléans]] in 1709; however, they seldom if ever used it. The title should theoretically have passed in 1747 to [[Prince Philip, Duke of Calabria]], the first great-grandson of the [[Louis, Grand Dauphin|''Grand Dauphin'']] that was neither a ''fils de France'' nor a ''petit-fils de France''; however, [[Louis XV]] left the title to the House of Orléans rather than to the Spanish branch of the Bourbons, which had renounced its right to succeed to the French throne by the [[Treaty of Utrecht]]. This meant that [[Louis Philippe II, Duke of Orleans|Louis Philippe]], duke of Orleans in the late 18th century, was the First Prince of the Blood immediately before the [[French Revolution]], entitling him to sit on various bodies, such as the [[Assembly of Notables#1787 assembly|1787 Assembly of Notables]], which he used as a platform to advocate liberal reforms.<ref>{{cite podcast |host=[[Mike Duncan (podcaster)|Mike Duncan]]|title=Episode 3.5 "The Assembly of Notables" |website=Revolutions |publisher= |date=17 August 2014|url=http://www.revolutionspodcast.com/2014/08/35-the-assembly-of-notables.html |access-date=18 April 2017}}</ref>
'''First Princes of the Blood, 1465–1830'''
:'''Valois House of Orléans''' {{ordered list|start=1 | 1465–1498: [[Louis XII of France|Louis II, Duke of Orléans]] (1462–1515); | 1498–1515: [[Francis I of France|François, Count of Angoulême]] (1494–1547) }} :'''House of Valois-Alençon''' {{ordered list|start=3 | 1515–1525: [[Charles IV, Duke of Alençon]] (1489–1525); }} :'''House of Bourbon-Montpensier''' {{ordered list|start=4 | 1525–1527: [[Charles III, Duke of Bourbon]] (1490–1527) would have been the first prince had he not been banned from the position for treason; }} :'''House of Bourbon-Vendôme''' {{ordered list|start=5 | 1527–1537: [[Charles of Bourbon, Duke of Vendôme|Charles IV de Bourbon, Duke of Vendôme]] (1489–1537); | 1537–1562: [[Antoine of Navarre|Antoine de Bourbon, Duke of Vendôme]], later [[King of Navarre]] (1518–1562). | 1562–1589: [[Henry IV of France|Henri III, King of Navarre]] (1553–1610); }} :'''[[Princes of Condé|House of Bourbon-Condé]]''' {{ordered list|start=8 | 1589–1646: [[Henry II, Prince of Condé|Henri II de Bourbon, Prince of Condé]] (1588–1646); | 1646–1686: [[Louis II, Prince of Condé|Louis II de Bourbon, Prince of Condé]] (1621–1686); | 1686–1709: [[Henry III, Prince of Condé|Henri III de Bourbon, Prince of Condé]] (1643–1709). }} :'''Bourbon [[House of Orléans]]''' {{ordered list|start=11 | 1709–1752: [[Louis d'Orléans, Duke of Orléans|Louis d'Orléans]] (1703–1752), as [[Duke of Chartres]] (1703–1723) and [[Duke of Orléans]] (1723–1752) | 1752–1785: [[Louis Philippe I, Duke of Orléans|Louis Philippe d'Orléans, Duke of Orléans]] (1725–1785); | 1785–1793: [[Louis Philippe II, Duke of Orléans|Louis Philippe Joseph d'Orléans, Duke of Orléans]] (1747–1793); | 1814–1830: [[Louis-Philippe I, King of the French|Louis Philippe d'Orléans, Duke of Orléans]] (1773–1850), who later ruled as [[Louis-Philippe I, King of the French]]. }}
<gallery class="center"> File:Antoine-de-bourbon.jpg|[[Antoine of Navarre|Antoine, Duke of Vendôme]] File:Full length Portrait of Louis de Bourbon, Prince of Condé, "Grand Condé" (1621-1686).jpg|''[[Louis II de Bourbon, Prince de Condé|Louis II, Prince of Condé]]'' by Joost van Egmont File:Louis d'Orleans.JPG|[[Louis d'Orléans, Duke of Orléans]] (1703-1752), [[Duke of Chartres]]; the first [[House of Orléans|Orléans]] [[Prince]] to use the style File:Louis Philippe Joseph d'Orléans.jpg|The last ''Monsieur le Prince'' of the Ancien Régime, [[Louis Philippe II, Duke of Orléans|Philippe Égalité]] </gallery>
==''Madame la Princesse''== This style was held by the wife of ''Monsieur le Prince''. The duchesses/princesses that were entitled to use it were: * 1646–1686: [[Claire-Clémence de Maillé-Brézé]] (1628–1694). Niece of [[Cardinal Richelieu]] and wife of the ''Grand Condé'', she was also the Duchess of Fronsac in her own right from 1646–1674. * 1684–1709: [[Anne Henriette of Bavaria|''Anna Henrietta'' Julia of Bavaria]] (1648–1723). She was the daughter of [[Anna Gonzaga]] and her husband [[Charles I, Duke of Mantua]]. In 1663 she married [[Henry III Jules de Bourbon, prince de Condé|Henry Jules, Duke of Bourbon]] the son and heir of the ''Grand Condé''. Anne Henriette was the mother of [[Louis III, Prince of Condé]] and ''[[Marie Thérèse de Bourbon|Madame la Princesse de Conti Seconde Douairière]]'' * 1709–1723: [[Françoise-Marie de Bourbon]] (1677–1749) – wife of [[Philippe II, Duke of Orléans]] * 1724–1726: [[Margravine Auguste Marie Johanna of Baden-Baden]] (1704–1726) – wife of [[Louis d'Orléans, Duke of Orléans|Louis of Orléans]] * 1743–1759: [[Louise Henriette de Bourbon]] – daughter of ''[[Louise Élisabeth de Bourbon|Madame la Princesse de Conti Dernière Douairière]]'' and wife of [[Louis Philippe I, Duke of Orléans|Louis Philippe d'Orléans, Duke of Orléans]] * 1785–1793: [[Louise Marie Adélaïde de Bourbon]] (1753–1821); wife of [[Louis Philippe II, Duke of Orléans|Louis Philippe Joseph d'Orléans, Duke of Orléans]]. She was the last holder of the style before the outbreak of the [[French Revolution]].
<gallery class="center"> File:Undated engraved portrait of Anne de Bavière by Marguerite Van der Mael.jpg|[[Anne Henriette of Bavaria]] File:Portrait painting of Françoise Marie de Bourbon, later Duchess of Orléans by François de Troy.jpg|[[Françoise-Marie de Bourbon]], did not use the style as her husband did not. File:Louise Henriette de Bourbon (1726–1759), depicted as the goddess Hebe by Nattier (Metropolitan Museum of Art).jpg|[[Louise Henriette de Bourbon]], mother of Philippe Égalité File:Portrait of Louise Marie Adélaïde de Bourbon by Vigée Lebrun.jpg|''[[Louise Marie Adélaïde de Bourbon|Madame la Princesse]]'' – wife of Philippe Égalité. </gallery>
==''Monsieur le Duc''== This style was used for the eldest son of the [[Princes of Condé|''Prince de Condé'']]. Originally, the eldest son was given the title of [[Duke of Enghien|''Duc d'Enghien'']], but that changed in 1709 when the Condés lost the rank of ''premier prince''. After that, the eldest son was often given the courtesy title of [[Duke of Bourbon|''Duc de Bourbon'']], which had been granted to [[Louis, Grand Condé|''le Grand Condé'']], and his eldest son was then given the title of ''duc d'Enghien''. # 1689–1709: [[Henry III, Prince of Condé|Henri I, Duke of Enghien]] (1643–1709); # 1709–1710: [[Louis III, Prince of Condé|Louis I, Duke of Enghien]] (1668–1710); # 1710–1740: [[Louis Henri, Duke of Bourbon|Louis II Henri, Duke of Enghien]] (1692–1740); # 1740–1818: [[Louis Joseph, Prince of Condé|Louis III Joseph, Duke of Enghien]] (1736–1818); # 1818–1830: [[Louis Henry II, Prince of Condé|Louis IV Henri, Duke of Enghien]] (1756–1830).
<gallery class="center"> File:Le Grand Condé with his son Henri Jules, Duke of Enghien (future Prince of Condé) by Claude Lefèbvre.jpg|''[[Louis II de Bourbon, Prince de Condé|le Grand Condé]]'' with his son [[Henry III Jules de Bourbon, prince de Condé|Henri I, Duke of Enghien]] File:1694 Portrait of Louis de Bourbon, Prince of Condé from the workshop of Rigaud (Versailles).jpg|''[[Louis III, Prince of Condé|Monsieur le Duc]]'' File:Louis IV Henri de Bourbon-Conde.jpg|''[[Louis Henri, Duke of Bourbon|Monsieur le Duc]]'' as son of [[Louis III, Prince of Condé]] </gallery>
==''Madame la Duchesse''== This style was used for the wife of ''Monsieur le Duc''. The most famous holder of this [[honorific]] was: * 1685–1709: [[Louise-Françoise de Bourbon]] (1673–1743) – The illegitimate daughter of [[Louis XIV of France|Louis XIV]] and his mistress, [[Françoise-Athénaïs, marquise de Montespan|Madame de Montespan]], she was married in May 1685, to [[Louis III, Prince of Condé]], then known by the [[courtesy title]] of ''[[Duke of Bourbon|duc de Bourbon]]''. Since his style at court was ''Monsieur le Duc'', she became known as ''Madame la Duchesse''. She later held onto the style even in her widowhood when she was the Princess of Condé. She was later known as ''Madame la Duchesse Douairière''.
'''Others included:''' * 1713–1720: [[Marie Anne de Bourbon (1689–1720)|Marie Anne de Bourbon]] (1689–1720) – first wife of [[Louis Henri, Duke of Bourbon]]; * 1728–1741: [[Landgravine Caroline of Hesse-Rotenburg]] (1714–1741) second wife of the Duke of Bourbon; * 1753–1760: [[Charlotte Élisabeth Godefride de Rohan]] (1737–1760) – wife of [[Louis Joseph de Bourbon, prince de Condé|Louis Joseph, Prince of Condé]] * 1770–1818: [[Bathilde d'Orléans|Louise Marie Thérèse ''Bathilde'' d'Orléans]] (1750–1820) – wife of the last Prince of Condé.
<gallery class="center"> File:Louise francoise bourbon.jpg|''[[Louise-Françoise de Bourbon|Madame la Duchesse]]''. She was the wife of ''[[Louis III, Prince of Condé|Monsieur le Duc]]'' File:Gobert, attributed - Marie Anne de Bourbon, Princess of Condé - Versailles, MV3758.jpg|[[Marie Anne de Bourbon (1689–1720)|Marie Anne, Princess of Condé]]; ''Madame la Duchesse'' due to the Condé loss of Mme la Princesse to the [[House of Orléans]] File:Bathilde d'Orléans, duchesse de Bourbon.gif|[[Bathilde d'Orléans|''Bathilde'' d'Orléans]] </gallery>
==''Monsieur le Comte''== This address was used by the head of the most junior branch of the House of Bourbon, the comte de Soissons. The comtes de Soissons, like the [[Princes of Conti]], descended from the [[Princes of Condé]]. The line started in 1566 when the Soissons title was given to [[Charles de Bourbon, comte de Soissons|Charles de Bourbon]], the second son of [[Louis I de Bourbon, prince de Condé]], the first ''Prince of Condé''.
The first Prince had three sons: * [[Henri I de Bourbon, prince de Condé|Henri de Bourbon]], second Prince of Condé; * [[Charles de Bourbon, comte de Soissons|Charles de Bourbon]], first Count of Soissons and the founder of the [[Princes of Condé#House of Bourbon-Soissons|House of Bourbon-Soissons]] * [[François, Prince of Conti|François de Bourbon, Prince de Conti]], first [[Princes of Conti|Prince of Conti]] but the Conti title lapsed upon his death in 1614 without legitimate heirs. It was later revived in 1629 for [[Armand de Bourbon, prince de Conti]], the second son of [[Henry II, Prince of Condé]].
The Soissons title was acquired by the first Prince of Condé in 1557 and was held by his descendants for two more generations: * [[Charles, Count of Soissons]] * [[Louis, Count of Soissons]]
<gallery class="center"> File:CharlesdeBourbonComtedeSoissonCustos.jpg|Charles de Bourbon, [[Count]] of [[Soissons]] File:Engraving of Louis de Bourbon (1604-1641), Count of Soissons by Matthäus Merian (1).png|[[Louis de Bourbon, comte de Soissons|Louis de Bourbon, Count of Soissons]] File:Olympia Mancini by Mignard.png|[[Olympia Mancini]], known as ''Madame la Comtesse'' at court </gallery>
The 2nd Count of Soissons died without an heir, so the Soissons title passed to his younger sister, [[Marie de Bourbon, Countess of Soissons|Marie de Bourbon]], the wife of [[Thomas Francis, Prince of Carignano]], a member of the [[House of Savoy]]. She became known as ''Madame la comtesse de Soissons''. On her death, the title passed first to her second son, [[Joseph-Emmanuel, Count of Soissons|Prince Joseph-Emmanuel of Savoy-Carignan]] (1631–1656), and then to her third son, [[Prince Eugène-Maurice of Savoy-Carignano|Prince Eugène-François of Savoy-Carignan]].
He married [[Olympia Mancini]], niece of [[Cardinal Mazarin]]. She was known as ''Madame la Comtesse de Soissons''<ref>[[Nancy Mitford]], ''The Sun King'', 1966, p.87</ref> like her mother-in-law. On his death, the title went to his eldest son, [[Prince Louis Thomas of Savoy-Carignano|Prince Louis-Thomas]], who was the older brother of the famous Austrian general, [[Prince Eugene of Savoy]]. The Soissons title became extinct upon the death of Prince Eugène-Jean of Savoy-Carignan in 1734.
==''Madame la Comtesse''== This style was used by the wife of ''Monsieur le Comte''. The best example of this is [[Olympia Mancini]].
==''Madame la Princesse Douairière''== In order to tell the wives of the various Princes of Conti apart after their deaths, the widows were given the name of ''Douairière'' (or [[dowager]]) and a number corresponding to when they lost their husband. After being widowed their full style would be ''Madame la Princesse de Conti 'number' Douairière''. Between 1727 and 1732, there were three widowed Princesses de Conti. They were: * [[Marie Anne de Bourbon]] (1666–1739), the legitimised daughter of [[Louis XIV]] and [[Louise de La Vallière]]; she was the wife of [[Louis Armand I, Prince of Conti]]. She was known as ''Madame la Princesse de Conti Première Douairière'' as she was the first to be widowed, in 1685. The title went to her husband's younger brother, [[François Louis, Prince of Conti]]. * [[Marie Thérèse de Bourbon]] (1666–1732), the wife of [[François Louis, Prince of Conti]]; she was known as ''Madame la Princesse de Conti Seconde Douairière'' after losing her husband in 1709. * [[Louise Élisabeth de Bourbon]] (1693–1775), the wife of [[Louis Armand II de Bourbon, prince de Conti|Louis Armand II, Prince of Conti]], the son and successor of [[François Louis, Prince of Conti]]. She was the daughter of ''[[Louis III, Prince of Condé|Monsieur le Duc]]'' and ''[[Louise-Françoise de Bourbon|Madame la Duchesse]]''. After her husband died in 1727, she was known as ''Madame la Princesse de Conti Troisième/Dernière Douairière''. This was not a traditional style by right but was simply a means the court used to distinguish between the three widows who held the title of ''[[Prince de Conti|Princesse de Conti]]'' at the same time.
<gallery class="center"> File:Mademoiselle de Blois (Marie Anne de Bourbon, 1666-1739) by François de Troy.jpg|''[[Marie Anne de Bourbon|Madame la Princesse de Conti Première Douairière]]'' File:Pierre Mignard portrait painting of Marie Thérèse de Bourbon (1666-1732), Princess of Conti.jpg|''[[Marie Thérèse de Bourbon|Madame la Princesse de Conti Seconde Douairière]]'' File:Portrait of Louise Élisabeth de Bourbon (1693-1775), Princess of Conti by Pierre Gobert.jpg|''[[Louise Élisabeth de Bourbon|Madame la Princesse de Conti Dernière Douairière]]'' </gallery>
==Legitimised royal offspring== [[Legitimation|Legitimised]] children of the King of France, and of other males of his dynasty, took surnames according to the branch of the [[House of Capet]] to which their father belonged, e.g. [[Louis-Auguste de Bourbon, duc du Maine]], was the elder son of [[Louis XIV of France|Louis XIV]] by his mistress, [[Françoise-Athénaïs, marquise de Montespan|Mme de Montespan]].<ref name="spanheim"/> After the legitimisation occurred, the child was given a title. Males were given titles from their father's lands and estates and females were given the style of ''Mademoiselle de X''. Examples of this are (children of Louis XIV and [[Françoise-Athénaïs, marquise de Montespan|Mme de Montespan]]): * Louise Françoise de Bourbon (1669–1672); [[File:The sisters Mademoiselle de Blois and Mademoiselle de Nantes by Philippe Vignon.jpg|thumb|right|200px|The sisters [[Françoise-Marie de Bourbon|''Mademoiselle de Blois'']] and [[Louise-Françoise de Bourbon|''Mademoiselle de Nantes'']], two legitimised daughters of Louis XIV and Mme de Montespan.]] * Louis-Auguste de Bourbon (1670–1736), titled [[Louis-Auguste de Bourbon, duc du Maine|''duc du Maine'']] – later married [[Anne-Louise-Bénédicte de Bourbon-Condé]]. * Louis César de Bourbon (1672–1683), titled [[Counts of the Vexin|''comte de Vexin'']]; * Louise-Françoise de Bourbon (1673–1743), titled [[Louise-Françoise de Bourbon|''Mademoiselle de Nantes'']] – later wife of [[Louis III, Prince of Condé|Louis III de Bourbon-Condé, ''prince de Condé'']] * Louise Marie Anne de Bourbon (1674–1681), titled [[Louise Marie Anne de Bourbon|''Mademoiselle de Tours'']]; * Françoise-Marie de Bourbon (1677–1749), titled [[Françoise-Marie de Bourbon|''Mademoiselle de Blois'']] – wife of [[Philippe II, Duke of Orléans|Philippe II d'Orléans]], ''[[Duke of Orléans|duc d'Orléans]]''. * Louis-Alexandre de Bourbon (1678–1737), titled [[Louis-Alexandre de Bourbon, comte de Toulouse|''comte de Toulouse'']] – later married to [[Marie Victoire de Noailles]].
Also the child would be referred to as ''Légitimé de Bourbon''; such as [[Marie Anne de Bourbon|Marie Anne ''légitimée de Bourbon'', ''mademoiselle de Blois'']] daughter of [[Louis XIV]] and [[Louise de La Vallière]]. Her full brother was [[Louis de Bourbon, comte de Vermandois|Louis de Bourbon]], later given the title of ''comte de Vermandois''.
==Orléans-Longueville== The branch of the ''ducs de Longueville'', extinct in 1672 (1694), bore the surname ''d'Orléans'', as legitimised descendants of [[Jean de Dunois|Jean, bâtard d'Orléans]], the [[wikt:illegitimate|natural]] son of a [[House of Valois|Valois]] prince who held the [[appanage]] of Orléans before the Bourbons did.<ref>ib. Spanheim, Ézéchiel, pp. 104–105.</ref> Non-legitimised natural children of royalty took whatever surname the king permitted, which might or might not be that of the [[dynasty]].
Children born out of [[Marriage|wedlock]] to a French king or prince were never recognised as ''fils de France''. However, if legitimised, the king might raise them to a rank just below or even equivalent to that of a ''prince du sang''.<ref>ib. Spanheim, Ézéchiel, pp. 100–105, 323–327.</ref>
==See also== *[[House of Condé]] *[[Princes of Orléans]] *[[Prince étranger]] *''[[wikt:Prinz|Prinz]]'', ''esp.'' in contrast to ''[[Fürst]]'' / ''[[Fuerst]]''

'''Prostitution in Ghana''' is illegal but widespread,<ref name="usstate">{{cite web|url=https://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/hrrpt/2008/af/119004.htm |title=2008 Human Rights Report: Ghana|publisher=State.gov|date=2009-02-25|accessdate=2015-05-20}}</ref><ref name="trust">{{cite report|url=http://www.trust.org/contentAsset/raw-data/1035fde5-b945-49ed-8cd4-166bc1ec156b/file |format=PDF |title=Overview of Trafficking and Prostitution Laws in the Middle East and Africa |publisher=Thomson Reuters Foundation|date=November 2012|accessdate=2017-03-12}}</ref> so much so that many Ghanaians are unaware that it is prohibited.<ref name="redef">{{cite web |url= https://www.atria.nl/epublications/1997/Redefining_Prostitution.pdf |title= Redefining Prostitution as Sex Work on the International Agenda |last= Bindman |first= Jo |last2= Doezema |first2= Jo |date= 1997 |website= Atria |publisher= |access-date= 28 November 2017 |quote= }}</ref> There are growing [[sex tourism]], [[child prostitution]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://pulse.com.gh/news/unicef-report-cape-coast-tops-child-prostitution-in-ghana-survey-id4122073.html|title=UNICEF report: Cape Coast tops child prostitution in Ghana – Survey – News – Pulse|first=Emmanuel|last=Tornyi|publisher=|accessdate=23 January 2017}}</ref> and [[human trafficking]].<ref name="gweb">{{cite web|url=http://www.ghanaweb.com/GhanaHomePage/NewsArchive/Prostitution-in-Ghana-279295|title=Prostitution in Ghana|publisher=|accessdate=23 January 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.state.gov/j/tip/rls/tiprpt/countries/2013/215470.htm|title=Ghana|publisher=|accessdate=23 January 2017}}</ref> High rates of unemployment and poverty in Ghana are believed to be causing a growth in the sex industry.<ref>{{cite thesis|url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/304446957|title=Gender and Livelihoods: Mapping the Economic Strategies of Porters in Accra, Ghana|first=Muriel A.|last=Yeboah|date=1 January 2008|degree=PhD |publisher=West Virginia University|accessdate=12 March 2017|via=Proquest}}</ref><ref name="auto">{{cite news|url=https://www.modernghana.com/news/682212/relationship-between-unemployment-and-prostitution-in-ghana.html|title=Relationship Between Unemployment And Prostitution In Ghana|first=Albert|last=Opare|date=24 March 2016|publisher=modernghana.com|accessdate=12 March 2017}}</ref> Unemployment is a reason teenage workers engage in sex work.<ref name=DW/><ref name="ency" /> A high percentage of sex workers are vulnerable to [[HIV]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.newstimeafrica.com/archives/31586 |title=IOM Study shows HIV vulnerability among female sex workers in Ghana|publisher=Newstimeafrica.com|date= |accessdate=2015-05-20}}</ref>
Some prostitutes in Ghana are campaigning for the sex trade to be legalised,<ref name="DW">{{cite news|url=http://www.dw.com/en/prostitutes-in-ghana-battle-for-recognition/av-17036797|title=Prostitutes in Ghana battle for recognition|publisher=Deutsche Welle|date=21 August 2013|author=Isaac Kaledzi}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ghanatrade.gov.gh/Latest-News/make-prostitution-legal-prostitutes-urge-govt.html|title=Make Prostitution Legal - Prostitutes Urge Gov't|publisher=ghanatrade.gov.gh|accessdate=12 March 2017}}</ref> and discussions have taken place.<ref name="trust" />
Ghana's former Prime Minister, [[Kofi Abrefa Busia|Dr Kofi Abrefa Busia]], an Oxford sociologist, wrote a thesis on prostitution “Report on a social survey of Sekondi-Takoradi.“<ref name="gweb" />
==Overview== Prostitutes in Ghana are known locally as "ashawo",<ref name="modern">{{cite web|url=https://www.modernghana.com/news/682212/relationship-between-unemployment-and-prostitution-in-ghana.html|title=Relationship Between Unemployment And Prostitution In Ghana|website=Modern Ghana|author=Albert Opare|date=24 March 2016}}</ref> "toutou" (derived from 'two shillings, two pence'; a prostitute who doesn't charge much)<ref name="ency">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=-5WyPfynlwMC&pg=PA534&lpg=PA534&dq=prostitution%20in%20ghana#v=onepage&q=prostitution%20in%20ghana&f=false|title=Encyclopedia of Prostitution and Sex Work|first=Melissa Hope|last=Ditmore|date=1 January 2006|publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group|accessdate=23 January 2017|via=Google Books|isbn=9780313329708}}</ref> or "maame-i-dey".<ref name="gweb" /> There are [[brothels]] in most Ghana towns, cities and ports. Often these are in makeshift shacks or old warehouses, and some are attached to bars.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.zammagazine.com/chronicle/chronicle-7/70-the-girls-behind-the-railway-line|title=The girls behind the railway line - ZAM|first=Selase|last=Kove-Seyram|publisher=|accessdate=12 March 2017}}</ref> Prostitutes not working in the brothels are known as either "seaters" or "roamers".<ref name="redef" /> The seaters work from home, sitting in the doorway and inviting customers in.<ref name="redef" /> When they are with a customer they lower a curtain in front of the door.<ref name="ency" /> Seaters generally work in one area of town, creating a small red-light district. Generally they are older women or widows.<ref name="redef" />
Roamers tend to be younger women and work on the streets, bars and hotels.<ref name="redef" /> "Pilots", often taxi-drivers, work as intermediaries between the women and clients in hotels. They usually get a fee from both parties.<ref name="redef" /> They also help the women get into the hotels as most have a no single women rule.<ref name="redef" /> Hotel staff may also take bribes to let the women in.<ref name="redef" />
The women face occasional violence from the customers, or more commonly refusal to pay. Hotel staff may exploit them.<ref name="redef" />
Since oil production started in 2011, prostitution in the port of [[Takoradi]] has risen sharply due to the influx of oil workers.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.rnw.nl/africa/article/ghana-oil-revives-prostitution|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120209022602/http://www.rnw.nl/africa/article/ghana-oil-revives-prostitution|archivedate=2014-02-03|title=Ghana: oil revives prostitution |author=Francis Kokutse |publisher=Radio Netherlands Worldwide|date=9 February 2012|accessdate=12 March 2017}}</ref>
[[UNAIDS]] estimate there are 52,000 prostitutes in the country.<ref>{{cite web |title=Sex workers: Population size estimate - Number, 2016 |url=http://www.aidsinfoonline.org/gam/stock/shared/dv/PivotData_2018_7_22_636678151733621264.htm |website=www.aidsinfoonline.org |publisher=UNAIDS |accessdate=21 July 2018}}</ref>
==Male prostitution== The prevalence of male prostitution in Ghana has slowly risen over the years but not much is said about it because of the form it takes. Male prostitution is predominant in the following areas such as [[Tesano]], [[Adabraka]], [[Osu, Accra]] and Paloma in Accra. Male prostitutes go undercover as women because homosexuality is illegal in Ghana as per the constitution.<ref>{{cite web|title=Male prostitutes practice openly in Accra|url=https://www.modernghana.com/lifestyle/376/16/male-prostitutes-practice-openly-in-accra.html|website=Modern Ghana|publisher=Modern Ghana|accessdate=24 April 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Ennin Abbey|first1=Emelia|title='Man-woman' prostitute arrested by police in Accra|url=https://www.graphic.com.gh/news/general-news/man-woman-prostitute-arrested-by-sowutuom-police.html|website=Graphic Online|publisher=Graphic Online|accessdate=24 April 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=PHOTO: Male prostitute dressed as a Female arrested Agbogbloshie|url=http://etvghana.com/2017/09/19/photo-male-prostitute-dressed-as-a-female-arrested-agbogbloshie/|website=e.tv Ghana|publisher=e.tv Ghana|accessdate=24 April 2018}}</ref> The activities of these prostitutes are most commonly patronized by men in the elite class who have enough resources to be discreet about their sexual activities.<ref>{{cite web|title=Gay Prostitutes Invade Accra|url=https://www.ghanaweb.com/GhanaHomePage/NewsArchive/Gay-Prostitutes-Invade-Accra-124290|website=GhanaWeb|publisher=GhanaWeb|accessdate=24 April 2018}}</ref> This leads to a relevant increase in the price of engaging homosexual prostitutes given the limited supply of these prostitutes.<ref>{{cite web|title=Male prostitutes practice openly in Accra|url=https://www.modernghana.com/lifestyle/376/16/male-prostitutes-practice-openly-in-accra.html|website=Modern Ghana|publisher=Modern Ghana|accessdate=24 April 2018}}</ref>
==Law enforcement== Law enforcement is variable, and there are also occasional crack-downs on prostitutes.<ref name="usstate" /> Prostitutes are often abused by law enforcement officers.<ref name="DW" /><ref name="redef" /> In a survey across 26 town and cities, a third of the prostitutes told of problems with the police. These included intimidation, extortion, threats and raids. Many reported that they had had to have sex with the officers to avoid prosecution.<ref name="redef" />
In a 2007 survey of 251 law enforcement agents, 15% admitted they had demanded sex in return for not prosecuting arrested prostitutes.<ref name="usstate" />
Police and politicians are sometimes bribed or blackmailed to turn a blind eye.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://pulse.com.gh/news/sin-city-how-prostitution-illicit-sex-and-immorality-rule-ashaiman-id4208969.html|title=Sin City? How prostitution, illicit sex and immorality rule Ashaiman – News – Pulse|first=Sena|last=Quashie|publisher=|accessdate=23 January 2017}}</ref>
==Sex tourism== Ghana has established itself as a destination for [[sex tourism]] from western tourists. This kind of tourism has attracted paedophiles due to the country's lax child protection laws and poor law enforcement.<ref>{{cite news|title=Ghana Trafficking China's Prostitutes|work=West African Democracy Radio|date= |url=http://wadr.org/en/site/news_en/2444/%27Ghana-Trafficking-China%27s-Prostitutes%27--EPAWA.htm |accessdate=2012-04-13}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://thechronicle.com.gh/children-active-in-commercial-sex-work-in-ghana/ |title=Children active in commercial sex work in Ghana|publisher=Thechronicle.com.gh|date=2012-06-05|accessdate=2015-05-20}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=ZJPT3XUM81AC&pg=PA104&lpg=PA104&dq=prostitution%20in%20ghana#v=onepage&q=prostitution%20in%20ghana&f=false|title=Children's Rights in Ghana: Reality or Rhetoric?|first1=Robert Kwame|last1=Ame|first2=DeBrenna LaFa|last2=Agbényiga|first3=Nana Araba|last3=Apt|date=22 February 2011|publisher=Lexington Books|accessdate=23 January 2017|via=Google Books|isbn=9780739169100}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/hrrpt/2006/78737.htm |title=Ghana|publisher=State.gov|date=2007-03-06|accessdate=2015-05-20}}</ref><ref name=RN>{{cite web|url=http://www.rnw.nl/africa/article/ghana-%E2%80%9Cparadise-paedophiles%E2%80%9D-says-oneworld|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120708201626/http://www.rnw.nl/africa/article/ghana-%E2%80%9Cparadise-paedophiles%E2%80%9D-says-oneworld|archivedate=2012-07-08|title=Ghana is "paradise for paedophiles", says OneWorld |date=8 July 2012|publisher=Radio Netherlands Worldwide |accessdate=12 March 2017}}</ref><ref name=Graphic>{{cite news|url=http://www.graphic.com.gh/features/features/ghana-not-a-sex-tourism-destination.html|title=Ghana news: Ghana not a sex tourism destination |date=2 July 2013|first=Arku|last=Jasmine|publisher=Graphic Online|accessdate=12 March 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.ecoi.net/local_link/308763/446602_de.html|title=Trafficking in Persons Report 2015 - Country Narratives - Ghana|author=US Department of State|date=27 July 2015|publisher=European Country of Origin Information Network|accessdate=12 March 2017}}</ref> [[Child prostitution]] is increasing is a problem with girls being vulnerable and boys to a lesser extent.<ref name=OW>{{cite news|url=https://www.oneworld.nl/wereld/paradijs-voor-pedos |author=Sanne Terlingen |title=Paradijs voor Pedo's |language=nl|publisher=OneWorld.nl |date=2012-06-28 |accessdate=2017-03-12}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.newstimeafrica.com/archives/31586|title=IOM Study shows HIV vulnerability among female sex workers in Ghana |date=15 April 2015 |publisher=Newstime Africa|agency=African Press Organization|accessdate=12 March 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ecpat.org/wp-content/uploads/legacy/Ex_Summary_GHANA_FINAL.pdf |format=PDF |title=Executive summary : Ghana |website=Ecpat.org |accessdate=2017-03-12}}</ref><ref name=ABC>{{cite news|last1=Clarke|first1=Prue|title=PM - Poverty in Ghana driving children into prostitution|url=http://www.abc.net.au/pm/content/2005/s1481873.htm|accessdate=12 March 2017|publisher=Australian Broadcasting Corporation|date=13 October 2005}}</ref><ref name=IN>{{cite web|url=http://www.irinnews.org/report/77388/ghana-profile-child-sex-worker|title=Profile of a child sex worker|date=20 March 2008|publisher=IRIN|accessdate=12 March 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Blay|first1=Pius Amihere|title=Cape Coast tops child prostitution in Ghana- UNICEF Report|url=http://citifmonline.com/2015/08/31/cape-coast-tops-child-prostitution-in-ghana-unicef-report/|publisher=Ghana News|date=31 August 2015}}</ref>
==Sex trafficking== {{see also|Human trafficking in Ghana}} Vietnamese prostitutes have been found in Ghana<ref>{{cite news |last=Adams |first=Issaka |date=March 12, 2014 |title=Vietnamese Prostitutes in Ghana Rescue: Ghana’s Finest Undercover Journalist Exposes Sex Slavery Trade / Africa News |url=http://www.nationalturk.com/en/vietnamese-prostitutes-in-ghana-rescue-sex-slavery-trade-africa-news-48323/ |newspaper=National Turk |location= |access-date= }}</ref> in the coastal cities of [[Tema]] and [[Takoradi]].<ref>{{cite news |last=Trung |first=Pham |date=28 March 2014 |title= Closer look at rescue of Vietnamese women from Ghana brothel |url=http://tuoitrenews.vn/society/18618/closer-look-at-vietnamese-women-saved-from-ghana-brothel |newspaper=Tuoitrenews |location= |access-date= }}</ref> Ghanaian investigative journalist [[Anas Aremeyaw Anas]] discovered that the Vietnamese women had been trafficked into Ghana for the purposes of prostitution.<ref>{{cite news |last= |first= |date= 21 March 2014 |title= Six Vietnamese women rescued from Ghana brothel |url=http://tuoitrenews.vn/society/18505/six-vietnamese-women-rescued-from-ghana-brothel |newspaper=Tuoitrenews |location= |access-date= }}</ref> The Vietnamese prostitutes had been recruited by a Vietnamese woman named Hanh in July 2013.<ref>{{cite news |last= |first= |date=21 Mar 2014 |title=Chinese prostitutes invade Ghana |url=https://www.newsghana.com.gh/chinese-prostitutes-invade-ghana/ |newspaper=News Ghana |location= |access-date= }}</ref> The price paid by their clients in Ghana was {{currency|amount=100|code=USD}} per hour.<ref>{{cite news |last= |first= |date=20 March 2014 |title=Vietnamese women forced into sex work in Ghana rescued |url=http://www.thanhniennews.com/society/vietnamese-women-forced-into-sex-work-in-ghana-rescued-24759.html |newspaper=Thanh Nien News |location= |access-date= }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last= |first= |date= 7 March 2014 |title=Vietnamese girls rescued from sex trade in Takoradi |url=http://citifmonline.com/2014/03/07/vietnamese-girls-rescued-from-sex-trade-in-takoradi/ |newspaper=citifmonline |location= |access-date= }}</ref> The prostitutes worked from a brothel in the Jang Mi Guest House in Takoradi.<ref>{{cite news |last=Anas |first=Anas Aremeyaw |date=12 March 2014 |title= Anas' undercover story: Trafficked and abused – how girls were sold from one trafficker to the other |url=http://www.myjoyonline.com/news/2014/March-12th/anas-undercover-story-trafficked-and-abused-how-girls-were-sold-from-one-trafficker-to-the-other.php |newspaper=New Crusading Guide |location=Takoradi |access-date= }}</ref> The women's ages ranged from 25 to 35.<ref>{{cite news |last=Ruha |first=Genevieve |date=8 March 2014 |title=Two Chinese Men Arrested In Takoradi For Trafficking Vietnamese Women There For Prostitution |url=http://www.ghanagrio.com/news/49112-two-chinese-men-arrested-in-takoradi-for-trafficking-vietnamese-women-there-for-prostitution.html |newspaper=GhanaNation |location= |access-date= }}</ref>
Women and girls from China, Nigeria, Côte d'Ivoire and Burkina Faso are also trafficked into Ghana for prostitution.<ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.state.gov/j/tip/rls/tiprpt/2010/142760.htm |title= Trafficking in Persons Report 2010 |last= |first= |date= |website= |publisher= US Departement of State |access-date= 28 November 2017 |quote= }}</ref>
The [[United States Department of State]] [[Office to Monitor and Combat Trafficking in Persons]] ranks Ghana as a '[[Trafficking in Persons Report#Ranking System|Tier 2]]' country.<ref name="state18">{{cite web |title=Ghana 2018 Trafficking in Persons Report |url=https://www.state.gov/j/tip/rls/tiprpt/countries/2018/282661.htm |website=U.S. Department of State |accessdate=26 July 2018}}</ref>

{{Infobox language |name=Putian |nativename={{sans-serif|Pó-chéng-uā}} / {{lang|cpx|莆田話}} |states=Southern [[China]] |region=[[Putian]], [[Fujian]] |speakers=? |familycolor=Sino-Tibetan |fam2=[[Varieties of Chinese|Chinese]] |fam3=[[Min Chinese|Min]] |fam4=[[Pu-Xian Min]] |isoexception=dialect |glotto=puti1238 |glottorefname=Putian |lingua=79-AAA-idb |notice=IPA }} '''Putian dialect''' ([[Pu-Xian Min]]: {{sans-serif|Pó-chéng-uā}} / {{lang|cpx|莆田話}}) is a dialect of [[Pu-Xian Min]] [[Chinese language|Chinese]] spoken in urban area of [[Putian]], which is a [[prefecture-level city]] in the southeast coast of [[Fujian]] province. ==Phonology== Putian dialect has 15 initials, 40 rimes and 7 tones. ===Initials=== {| class="wikitable" border="1" style="text-align:center" |+ |- ! colspan="2" |   ! Nasal Coda {{IPA|/-ŋ/}} !! Glottal Coda {{IPA|/-ʔ/}} |- ! rowspan="6" | [[Four hu|open mouth]] | {{IPA link|a}} 鴉 | {{IPA|au}} 拗 | {{IPA|aŋ}} 江 | {{IPA|aʔ}} 壓 |- | {{IPA link|ɒ}} 奥 | | {{IPA|ɒŋ}} 王 | {{IPA|ɒʔ}} 屋 |- | {{IPA link|o}} 科 | {{IPA|ɔu}} 烏 | {{IPA|ɔŋ}} 温 | {{IPA|ɔʔ}} 熨 |- | {{IPA link|e}} 裔 | {{IPA|ai}} 愛 | {{IPA|ɛŋ}} 煙 | {{IPA|ɛʔ}} 黑 |- | {{IPA link|ø}} 改 | | {{IPA|œŋ}} 熊 | {{IPA|œʔ}} 郁 |- | | | {{IPA link|ŋ}} 伓 | |- ! rowspan="2" | [[Four hu|even teeth]] | {{IPA link|i}} 衣 | {{IPA|iu}} 油 | {{IPA|iŋ}} 引 | {{IPA|iʔ}} 益 |- | {{IPA|ia}} 夜 | {{IPA|iau}} 要 | {{IPA|iaŋ}} 鹽 | {{IPA|iaʔ}} 葉 |- ! rowspan="2" | [[Four hu|closed mouth]] | {{IPA link|u}} 夫 | {{IPA|ui}} 位 |'' {{IPA|uŋ}}'' 廣 | |- | {{IPA|ua}} 画 | {{IPA|uai}} 歪 | {{IPA|uaŋ}} 碗 | {{IPA|uaʔ}} 活 |- ! rowspan="2" | [[Four hu|round mouth]] | {{IPA link|y}} 余 | | {{IPA|yŋ}} 恩 | {{IPA|yʔ}} 役 |- | {{IPA|yɒ}} 安 | | {{IPA|yɒŋ}} 羊 | {{IPA|yɒʔ}} 藥 |} ===Tones=== {| class="wikitable" |+ |- |'''No.''' |1 |2 |3 |4 |5 |6 |7 |- |'''Tones''' |'''dark level'''

陽入 |- |'''Tone contour''' |{{IPA|˥˧˧}} (533) |{{IPA|˩˧}} (13) |{{IPA|˦˥˧}} (453) |{{IPA|˦˨}} (42) |{{IPA|˩˩}} (11) |{{IPA|ʔ˨˩}} (ʔ21) |{{IPA|ʔ˦}} (ʔ4) |- |'''Example Hanzi''' |詩巴 |時爬 |始把 |試霸 |寺罷 |濕北 |實拔 |- |} ===Assimilation=== {| class="wikitable" |- ! bgcolor="#ABCDEF"| ! bgcolor="#ABCDEF"|Coda of

Former Syllable ! bgcolor="#ABCDEF"|Initial of
the Latter Syllable |- | rowspan="4"|Group A | rowspan="4"|Open syllable | {{IPAslink|p}}, {{IPAslink|pʰ}} | rowspan="12"| → | rowspan="4"|''remain unchanged'' | {{IPAslink|β}}, {{IPAslink|ɣ}} |- | {{IPAslink|t}}, {{IPAslink|tʰ}}, {{IPAslink|ts}}, {{IPAslink|tsʰ}}, {{IPAslink|ɬ}} | {{IPAslink|l}} |- | {{IPAslink|k}}, {{IPAslink|kʰ}}, {{IPAslink|h}} | {{IPAslink|ɣ}} |- | {{IPAslink|m}}, {{IPAslink|n}}, {{IPAslink|l}}, {{IPAslink|ŋ}}, null initial | ''remain unchanged'' |- style="border-top-style:double;" | rowspan="4"|Group B | rowspan="4"|{{IPA|/-ŋ/}} (nasal coda) | {{IPAslink|p}}, {{IPAslink|pʰ}} | {{IPA|/-m/}} | {{IPAslink|m}} |- | {{IPAslink|t}}, {{IPAslink|tʰ}}, {{IPAslink|ts}}, {{IPAslink|tsʰ}}, {{IPAslink|l}}, {{IPAslink|ɬ}} | {{IPA|/-n/}} | {{IPAslink|n}}, ''remain unchanged'' |- | {{IPAslink|k}}, {{IPAslink|kʰ}}, {{IPAslink|h}}, null initial | ''remain unchanged'' | {{IPAslink|ŋ}} |- | {{IPAslink|m}}, {{IPAslink|n}}, {{IPAslink|ŋ}} | {{IPA|/-m/}}, {{IPA|/-n/}}, {{IPA|/-ŋ/}} | ''remain unchanged'' |- style="border-top-style:double;" | rowspan="4"|Group C | rowspan="4"|{{IPA|/-ʔ/}} (glottal Coda) | {{IPAslink|p}}, {{IPAslink|pʰ}}, {{IPAslink|m}} | {{IPA|/-p̚/}} | rowspan="4"|''remain unchanged'' |- | {{IPAslink|t}}, {{IPAslink|tʰ}}, {{IPAslink|ts}}, {{IPAslink|tsʰ}}, {{IPAslink|ɬ}}, {{IPAslink|l}}, {{IPAslink|n}} | {{IPA|/-t̚/}} |- | {{IPAslink|k}}, {{IPAslink|kʰ}}, {{IPAslink|ŋ}}, {{IPAslink|h}} | {{IPA|/-k̚/}} |- | null initial | {{IPA|/-ʔ/}} |- |} ===Tone sandhi=== Putian dialect has extremely extensive tone [[sandhi]] rules: in an utterance, only the last syllable pronounced is not affected by the rules. The two-syllable tonal sandhi rules are shown in the table below (the rows give the first syllable's original citation tone, while the columns give the citation tone of the second syllable): {|class=wikitable |+ Tone sandhi of first syllable |- | | bgcolor="#88AAFF"|'''dark level'''

13 | bgcolor="#88AAFF"|'''rising'''

42 | bgcolor="#88AAFF"|'''light departing'''
11 | bgcolor="#88AAFF"|'''dark entering'''
ʔ21 | bgcolor="#88AAFF"|'''light entering'''
ʔ4 |- | bgcolor="#9CFF88"|'''dark level'''
533 |colspan="3"|11 |colspan="3"|13 |11 |- | bgcolor="#9CFF88"|'''light level'''
13 |colspan="3"|11 |55 |colspan="2"|42 |11 |- | bgcolor="#9CFF88"|'''rising'''
453 |colspan="2"|13 |11 |colspan="3"|13 |11 |- | bgcolor="#9CFF88"|'''dark departing'''
42 |55 |42 |colspan="2"|55 |colspan="2"|42 |55 |- | bgcolor="#9CFF88"|'''light departing'''
11 |colspan="3"|11 |55 |colspan="2"|42 |55 |- | bgcolor="#9CFF88"|'''dark entering'''
ʔ21 |colspan="7"|ʔ4 |- | bgcolor="#9CFF88"|'''light entering'''
ʔ4 |colspan="7"|ʔ21 |- |} ==References== {{Reflist}} *{{cite book|author=Compilation Commission of Chorography of Putian City 福建省莆田市地方志编纂委员会|title=Pu tian shi zhi ''莆田市志 ["Chorography of Putian City"]''|url=http://www.fjsq.gov.cn/frmBokkList.aspx?key=598FF82EB2AF4A7784A8245692179F87|volume=43|publisher=Fangzhi chubanshe 方志出版社 ["Chorography Press"]|location=Beijing|year=2001|isbn=7-80122-669-0}} {{Min Chinese}} {{Languages of Taiwan}} [[Category:Pu-Xian Min]] [[Category:Languages of Taiwan]]

revision.text:
'''Right on Crime''' is a U.S. [[criminal justice reform]] initiative that aims to gain support for criminal justice reforms within the American conservative movement by sharing research and policy ideas, mobilizing conservative leaders, and by raising public awareness.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Altman|first1=Alex|title=Bipartisan Push for Criminal Justice Reform Sets Its Agenda|url=http://time.com/3931188/criminal-justice-reform-agenda/|accessdate=21 December 2015|publisher=Time|date=June 23, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Bauer|first1=Shane|title=How Conservatives Learned to Love Prison Reform|url=https://www.motherjones.com/politics/2014/02/conservatives-prison-reform-right-on-crime|accessdate=21 December 2015|publisher=Mother Jones|date=March 2014}}</ref> Right On Crime reforms are focused on "reducing crime, lowering costs and restoring victims." The initiative primarily focuses on eight issues: over-criminalization, [[American juvenile justice system|juvenile justice]], [[substance abuse]], [[Probation|adult probation]], [[parole]] and re-entry, [[law enforcement]], [[prison]]s and victims. Right on Crime is a project of the Center for Effective Justice at the [[Texas Public Policy Foundation]], a conservative think tank, and [[Prison Fellowship]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Lu|first1=Rachel|title=How Conservatives Are Getting Right On Crime|url=http://thefederalist.com/2015/02/03/how-conservatives-are-getting-right-on-crime/|accessdate=21 December 2015|publisher=The Federalist|date=February 3, 2015}}</ref>
== Background ==
The Right on Crime initiative began its public affairs campaign in December 2010, in Washington, D.C.<ref>{{cite web|author=Gritsforbreakfast |url=http://gritsforbreakfast.blogspot.com/2010/12/tppf-launches-right-on-crime-campaign.html |title=Grits for Breakfast: TPPF launches 'Right on Crime' campaign |publisher=Gritsforbreakfast.blogspot.com |date=2010-12-13 |accessdate=2013-12-23}}</ref> According to a January 2011 article in the ''Washington Post'' by former U.S. Speaker of the House Newt Gingrich and former California Speaker of the House Pat Nolan, "The Right on Crime Campaign represents a seismic shift in the legislative landscape. And it opens the way for a common-sense left-right agreement on an issue that has kept the parties apart for decades."<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2011/01/06/AR2011010604386.html|title=Prison reform: A smart way for states to save money and lives|work=[[Washington Post]]|author=[[Newt Gingrich]]|date=7 January 2011}}</ref> ''The New York Times''' [[Charlie Savage]] noted the conservative movement's growing support for Right on Crime in a ''Times'' editorial in October 2011, writing "The [corrections overhaul] movement has attracted the support of several prominent conservatives, including Edwin R. Meese III, the attorney general during the Reagan administration. He is part of a campaign, called 'Right on Crime,' which was begun last December to lend weight to what it calls the 'conservative case for reform.'"<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/08/13/us/13penal.html?_r=2&|work=New York Times|title=Trend to Lighten Harsh Sentences Catches On in Conservative States|date=12 August 2011|author=[[Charlie Savage]]}}</ref>
Beginning in 2011, Right on Crime expanded its campaign into individual states, including Texas,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.statesman.com/blogs/content/shared-gen/blogs/austin/politics/entries/2011/02/16/right_on_crime_launches_texas.html|work=Austin Statesman|title=Right on Crime launches Texas drive|date=16 February 2011}}</ref> Georgia,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://georgiapolicy.org/right-on-crime-launches-criminal-justice-reform-initiative-today-in-georgia/|publisher=Georgia Public Policy Foundation|title=Right on Crime Launches Criminal Justice Reform Initiative Today in Georgia|date=29 September 2011}}</ref> Oklahoma<ref>{{cite web|url=http://capitolbeatok.com/reports/right-on-crime-launches-oklahoma-effort-with-blue-room-conference |title=Right on Crime launches Oklahoma effort with Blue Room conference |publisher=Capitolbeatok.com |date=2011-03-15 |accessdate=2013-12-23}}</ref> and Florida. The ''Los Angeles Times'' explained the initiative is "setting the pace in states such as Texas," in a November 2011 editorial.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2011/nov/13/opinion/la-ed-realign-20111113|title=Prison realignment done right|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=13 November 2011}}</ref>
In 2014, the [[BBC]] reported that in Texas, rather than building new prisons, Right on Crime has led to the closure of three prisons.<ref name=BBC>{{cite news|title=Why Texas is closing prisons in favour of rehab|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-30275026|accessdate=2 December 2014|work=BBC|date=2 December 2014}}</ref>
== ''Statement of Principles'' signatories == Right On Crime's ''Statement of Principles'' has been signed by the following individuals:
* [[David Barton (author)|David Barton]], WallBuilders * [[William Bennett|William J. Bennett]], former Secretary of Education and Federal "Drug Czar" * [[Allan Bense]], former Speaker of the Florida House * [[Matthew Brouillette]], [[Commonwealth Foundation]] (PA) * [[Jeb Bush]],<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/09/02/idUS143110+02-Sep-2011+PRN20110902|title=Jeb Bush Signs Right On Crime Statement of Principles (press release)|newspaper=Reuters}}</ref><ref name="rightoncrime_a">{{cite web|url=http://www.rightoncrime.com/the-conservative-case-for-reform/statement-of-principles/|publisher=Right on Crime|title=Statement of Principles|accessdate=2013-12-23}}</ref> Former Governor of Florida * [[Charles Colson|Chuck Colson]],<ref>{{cite web|author=Gritsforbreakfast |url=http://gritsforbreakfast.blogspot.com/2012/04/chuck-colson-rip.html |title=Grits for Breakfast: Chuck Colson, RIP |publisher=Gritsforbreakfast.blogspot.com |date=2012-04-22 |accessdate=2013-12-23}}</ref> former President and CEO of [[Prison Fellowship]] * [[Ward Connerly]], [[American Civil Rights Institute]] and former Regent of University of California * [[Craig DeRoche]],<ref>{{cite web|author=Pat Shellenbarger |url=http://bridgemi.com/2012/02/with-a-sober-eye-a-conservative-reconsiders/ |title=Bridge • The Center for Michigan : With a sober eye, a conservative reconsiders |publisher=Bridge Magazine |date=2012-03-06 |accessdate=2013-12-23}}</ref> former Speaker of the Michigan House of Representatives and Vice President of Advocacy and Public Policy at [[Prison Fellowship]] * [[John J. DiIulio, Jr.]], [[University of Pennsylvania]] * [[Viet D. Dinh|Viet Dinh]], [[Georgetown University Law Center]] and former U.S. Assistant Attorney General * [[Richard E. Doran|Richard Doran]], former Florida Attorney General * [[Newt Gingrich]],<ref name="washingtonpost">{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2011/01/06/AR2011010604386.html |author=Newt Gingrich and Pat Nolan |title=Prison reform: A smart way for states to save money and lives |work=[[Washington Post]] |date=2011-01-07 |accessdate=2013-12-23}}</ref> [[American Solutions for Winning the Future]] * [[B. Wayne Hughes, Jr.]], Businessman/philanthropist * [[Asa Hutchinson]],<ref name="pewtrusts" /> former U.S. Attorney and Administrator of the U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration * [[Henry Juszkiewicz]],<ref>{{cite news|last=Juszkiewicz |first=Henry |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052702303830204577448351409946024 |title=Henry Juszkiewicz: Gibson's Fight Against Criminalizing Capitalism |work=[[Wall Street Journal]] |date=2012-07-19 |accessdate=2013-12-23}}</ref> CEO of Gibson Guitar * [[David Keene]], American Conservative Union * [[George Kelling]], [[Manhattan Institute for Policy Research|Manhattan Institute]] * Rabbi [[Daniel Lapin]], [[American Alliance of Jews and Christians]] * [[Edwin Meese|Edwin Meese III]],<ref name="pewtrusts" /> former U.S. Attorney General * [[B.J. Nikkel]], former Republican House Majority Whip, Colorado House of Representatives * [[Pat Nolan]],<ref name="washingtonpost" /> [[Prison Fellowship|Justice Fellowship]] * [[Grover Norquist]],<ref name="pewtrusts">{{cite web|url=http://www.pewtrusts.org/news_room_detail.aspx?id=85899362587 |title=The Smart Way to Get Tough on Crime (Spring 2011 Trust Magazine Article) - |publisher=[[The Pew Charitable Trusts]] |date= |accessdate=2013-12-23}}</ref> [[Americans for Tax Reform]] * [[Tony Perkins (politician)|Tony Perkins]], [[Family Research Council]] * [[Ralph E. Reed, Jr.|Ralph Reed]], Founder of the Faith and Freedom Coalition * [[Brooke Rollins]],<ref>{{cite web|last=Gramm |first=Wendy |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052702304203604577398543103817030 |title=Wendy Gramm and Brooke Rollins: Why the Left Wants to Blacklist ALEC - WSJ.com |publisher=Wall Street Journal |date=2012-05-15 |accessdate=2013-12-23}}</ref> [[Texas Public Policy Foundation]] * [[Tom Slade, Jr.|Tom Slade]], former Chairman of the Florida Republican Party * [[Larry Thompson]], former U.S. Deputy Attorney General * [[Richard Viguerie]], ConservativeHQ.com * [[J. C. Watts]], former member of the U.S. House of Representatives for Oklahoma's 4th Congressional District * [[Joe D. Whitley|Joe Whitley]], former Acting U.S. Associate Attorney General and U.S. Attorney
== References == {{Reflist}}

revision.text:
'''Tanomoshiko''' (also spelt '''Tanomoshi-ko''' or '''Tanomosiko''') ({{lang-ja|頼母子講}}) ("reliable group")<ref name="McTaggart2011" /> is a variety of [[rotating savings and credit association]] (ROSCA) found in Japan. Historically they played a major role in economic life in Japan and among the [[Japanese diaspora]], and still survive on an informal basis in some parts of the country.
==Name== ''Tanomoshi'' or ''Tanomoshiko'' (頼母子講) has also been called ''mujin'' (無尽) or ''moai'' (模合) in Japan. The name may be derived from ''tanomu'' meaning begging, or from ''tayori ni naru mono'' meaning reliance.<ref name=ACRN />
==History== ''Tanomoshi'', denoting a locally organized social finance scheme, has existed in Japan at least since the middle [[Kamakura period]] (1185–1333).<ref name="Odo2013" /> The principle was that each member would contribute a sum at regular intervals and would receive a single payment when their turn came round; it required mutual trust among those involved.<ref name="HolliJones1995" /> The institution facilitated personal savings, investment in property and enterprise, insurance, personal loans and assistance of poorer people. By the [[Edo period|Tokugawa period]] (1603–1868) ''tanomoshi'' was widespread.<ref name="Odo2013" /> During the later 19th century under the [[Meiji period|Meiji]], commercial [[bank]]s developed, but as the banks were reluctant to offer small-scale and personal banking services they did not altogether supersede ''tanomoshi'', which were incorporated into mutually financed ''mujin'' companies in 1915.<ref name="Tatewaki2012">{{cite book|author=Kazuo Tatewaki|title=Banking and Finance in Japan (RLE Banking & Finance): An Introduction to the Tokyo Market|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=fXAQxdFMxZMC&pg=PA9|date=12 October 2012|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-136-26906-6|page=9}}</ref> Neither was ''tanomoshi'' fully replaced by state [[social security]] when it was implemented in the early 20th century. The system also operated among Japanese immigrants to the United States and Brazil, helping them in establishing new businesses there.<ref name="HolliJones1995">{{cite book|author1=Melvin Holli|author2=Peter d'Alroy Jones|title=Ethnic Chicago: A Multicultural Portrait|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2JbU1d9Xil0C&pg=PA415|date=19 May 1995|publisher=Wm. B. Eerdmans Publishing|isbn=978-0-8028-7053-7|page=415}}</ref><ref name="Carvalho2003">{{cite book|author=Daniela de Carvalho|title=Migrants and Identity in Japan and Brazil: The Nikkeijin|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7nlxybOVae8C&pg=PT33|date=27 August 2003|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-135-78765-3|page=33}}</ref> Indeed while it diminished in Japan itself it remained of great importance to overseas Japanese communities.<ref name="Odo2013">{{cite book|author=Franklin Odo|title=Voices from the Canefields: Folksongs from Japanese Immigrant Workers in Hawai'i|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EVOwAAAAQBAJ&pg=PA34|date=October 2013|publisher=OUP USA|isbn=978-0-19-981303-2|pages=34–35}}</ref>
The institution went into decline after World War II, with the further growth of commercial banks and social security and the loosening of community bonds, but still exists in some parts of Japan.<ref name=ACRN>Sachiko Nakagawa, [http://www.acrn-journals.eu/resources/jfrp0403a.pdf "A Role of Social Finance by a Cooperative: A Case Study of Green Coop Fukuoka, Japan",] ''ACRN Journal of Finance and Risk Perspectives Special Issue of Social and Sustainable Finance'', Vol. 4 Issue 3, July 2015, pp. 1–18. ISSN 2305-7394</ref> During the 1970s there were estimated to be 20–30 ''tanomoshi'' groups involving economically better-off members of ''[[Buraku]]'' communities.<ref name="VosWagatsuma1972">{{cite book|author1=George A. De Vos|author2=Hiroshi Wagatsuma|title=Japan's Invisible Race: Caste in Culture and Personality|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=T0_EWolOfpUC&pg=PA173|year=1972|publisher=University of California Press|page=173|id=GGKEY:A1TPE4UELKE}}</ref>
==Current== {{refimprove section|date=March 2016}} ''Tanomoshi'' still functions in certain areas, especially [[Kyushu]] and [[Okinawa]]. For example, in Okinawa prefecture, ''tanomoshi'' is active under the name of ''moai'',<ref name="McTaggart2011">{{cite book|author=Lynne McTaggart|title=The Bond: How to Fix Your Falling-Down World|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-9mS384uKd4C&pg=PA198|date=19 April 2011|publisher=Simon and Schuster|isbn=978-1-4516-1052-9|pages=197–8}}</ref> and a [[local currency]] called Moai Cho has been sold in a stationery store (e.g., Editorial Team for Encyclopedia to Know Okinawa, 2000; Shimokawa, 2006). In Aizu region of Fukushima prefecture, ''tanomoshi'' called ''mujin'' has supported savings for leisure mainly in restaurants once a month (e.g., Kimura, 2001). However, in general, it is considered that traditional financial services based on mutual help and solidarity is not necessary anymore. Instead, consumer loans emerged as a new way to borrow money.
Most ''tanomoshiko'' are organized within a workplace or among friends. The members may use the funds built up to finance a trip or a banquet. It is most used by members of social minorities who are less prone to borrow money from financial institutions. The institution has little or no legal status.
==See also== *[[:ja:無尽]]
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Rotating savings and credit association]] [[Category:Microfinance in Asia]] [[Category:Collaborative finance]] [[Category:Japanese society]] [[Category:Economic history of Japan]] [[Category:Informal economy in Asia]]

revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=March 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2017}} The '''Thadou''' (''Thadou/Thado te'') are an ethnic group inhabiting in [[Northeast India]], Chin state and Sagaing Division in [[Burma]] and eastern [[Bangladesh]]. [[Thadou language|Thadou]] is a language of the Tibeto-Burman family. Thadou is spoken in the different parts of North East India and adjacent portions of Burma and Bangladesh. It was the second language after Meiteilon (Manipuri) in the Manipur state during British Colonial Period. In Manipur, the Thadous are mostly found in Churachandpur district, Senapati district, Ukhrul district, South-Western Hills and Sadar Hills, Chandel district and Jiribam. They are the largest Tribe in Manipur according to Manipur census 2011. Thadous also live in Mizoram, Nagaland and Assam, etc.
==Religion== A great majority of the Thadou people are Christians. Christianity among the Thadous can be traced back to an [[Anglican Church|Anglican]] named [[William Pettigrew]] who worked in Manipur as a missionary from 1894. The 100th anniversary of the Thadou people embracing Christianity was held at Motbung, Sadar Hills, Manipur India on 13 December 2008 under the aegis of the Thadou Baptist Association. Some 10% of the Thadou populace around the world are following [[Judaism]] as they are believed to be descendants of [[Manasseh]], one of the 12 tribes of [[Israel]]. Some 5000 of Thadou people are now settled in Israel.
==History== The Thadou people believed that Chongthu, a great Chief of Thadou, emerged out from a cave called "Chhinlung or [[Sinlung|Shinlung]] or Khul" the location of which was believed to be somewhere in Central China, whereas others claimed it to be in [[Tibet]]. (Ginzatuang 1973:5) Mc. Culloch (1857:55). Those ancestors emerging from the cave include Chongthu/Songthu, Khupngam, Vangalpa and some clansmen, leaving behind Noimangpa, Chongja and others of the group.
William Shaw's (1929) description about the origin of Thadou is recorded from collected oral traditionals. According to the Thadou narrative recorded by Shaw (1929), Noimangpa was the chief of subterranean region. Chongthu, a relative of Noimangpa, while hunting in the jungle with his dog, discovered a large cave. Chongthu, rejoiced at this discovery, gave up his hunting and went back to his village. He conjured up ideas of forming his own village on the earth. Meanwhile, Noimangpa the chief of the underworld was performing the ‘chon’ festival, in which everyone including chongja, the elder brother of Chongthu, Noimangpa’s son Chonkim participated. During this feast Chongthu started waving his sword so vigorously that he injured some of the people present, at which all were annoyed. This action of Chongthu was premeditated so that he can find an excuse to go to the upper world to form a village of his own. When Noimangpa came to know this he wanted Chongthu dead. Chongthu on hearing Noimangpa’s wrath, prepared to leave for the uninhabited earth, ‘khul’, as spoken of by the Thadous. So, Chongja and Chongthu along with the cavemen feasted before their departure. On their journey to the upper crust of the earth there was a great darkness, which lasted for seven days and seven nights, called “Thimzin” by the Thadou’s. They found a stone blocking their passage out and after making many attempts Chongja and party gave up and returned to Noimangpa and reported the result’. Pi Nemneh, wife of Songja, cursed Chongthu and party for leaving them at doom in ‘Khul’. It is also believed that Chongja, Noimangpa and other clansmen who were left behind are assimilated with the Chinese and Japanese people. [[File:Thadou men.jpg|thumb|right|A group of Thadou men]]
===The Anglo-Kuki War (1917–19)=== [[File:Pu Khotinthang Sitlhou @ Kilkhong.jpg|thumbnail|right|A life size statue of Pu Khotinthang Sitlhou (Chief of Jampi)]] The Kuki Rebellion (1917–19) was one of the important uprisings against the British imperialism which went on par with the Indian National Movement for Freedom. This movement was known by different names. The Thadous called it "Thadou gal". The Meiteis called it "Khongjai Laal"(Khongjai war). The Zous called it Zougal . However, in the official records of Manipur it was known as Kuki Rebellion 1917–1919. It commenced from 17 March 1917 and concluded on 20 May 1919
As a mark of protest against the British and to stop further recruitment of the Thadous and its cognate tribes in the non-combatant force at the battlefront in France in the First World War as per the appeal received from the Secretary of State for India, London, in his telegram dated 28 January 1917, the Thadous in Manipur openly revolted against the British in the month of December 1917. The Chief of Aisan, '''Chengjapao Doungel''', who was the "Piba" or head of the Thadous, sent orders to all the leading Thadou chiefs to resist the British with force, if necessary. A very important meeting was held at Jampi Village. The chiefs who attended the meeting were:
#Pu '''Khotinthang Sitlhou''' alias '''Kilkhong''', Chief of Jampi #Pu '''Khupkhotintong (Tintong) Haokip''' #Pu '''Songchung Sitlhou''', Chief of Sangnao #Pu '''Lunkholal Sitlhou''', Chief of Chongjang #Pu '''Vumngul Kipgen''', Chief of Tujang #Pu '''Lhunjangul Kipgen''', son of Vumngul Kipgen #Pu '''Enjakhup Kholhou''', Chief of Thenjang #Pu '''Leothang Haokip''', Chief of Goboh #Pu '''Mangkho-on Haokip''', Chief of Tingkai #Pu '''Heljason Haokip''', Chief of Loibol #Pu '''Onpilen Haokip''', Chief of Joupi #Pu '''Onpilal Haokip''', Chief of Santing #Pu '''Jamkhokhup''', Chief of Boljang #Pu '''Nguljahen Haokip''' of Boljang
The Thadous chiefs appointed Khupkhotintong Haokip as Field Commander of the war. Khotinthang Sitlhou (Kilkhong), the Chief of Jampi killed one Mithun to entertain the chiefs and "Sajam" was distributed to all the chiefs. Thus, a powerful conspiracy of the Thadou chiefs was established. And the '''Singson''' chief cut off the tail of a mithun as a mark of declaration of war against the British government on behalf of his clan. In Manipur, the rebellion spread like wild-fire, particularly in the Thadou inhabited areas – Jampi, Dulen, Sangnao, Khauchangbung and Laijang in the west; Chasat and Maokot in the east; Mombi and Lonza in the south-east and Henglep and Loikhai/Ukha in the southwest.
After many months of aggressive fight between the tenacious Thadou warriors and the mighty British force the Thadou Rebellion finally came to an end on 20 May 1919, with the subjugation of the Thadou by the British Rulers. The colonial authorities recorded the war as 'Kuki Rebellion" however, the Thadou and its cognate tribes called it Thadou gal. Sir Nicholar Beatson Bell, the former Chief Commissioner of Assam, also said that the Anglo-Kuki War, 1917–19 was confined entirely to the Thadous.
===Modern history=== Thadou<ref>Thadous are the single largest tribe in Manipur as per population census 2011.</ref> has been recognised as [[List of Scheduled Tribes in India|Scheduled Tribe in India]] since 1956. The followings covered under the Amended Vide Govt. of India Ministry of Law Notification Order No. S.R.O. 2477A, dated 29 October 1956, New Delhi, India.
Thadou subgroups (clans) are as follows. {{div col|colwidth=22em}} #Guite #Doungel #Sitlhou #Singsit #Kipgen #Haokip #Chongloi #Hangshing #Touthang #Lotjem #Haolai #Tuboi #Sa’um #Khuolhou #Lupho #Lupheng #Misao #Mate #Baite #Lhungdim #Ngailut #Kiloung #Insun #Jongbe #Lunkim #Lienthang #Thangngeo #Changsan #Lhang'um #Khuongthang {{div col end}}
==Marriage== There are four forms of marriages among the Thadou: ''chongmou, sahapsat, jol-lhah','kijam mang''. The latter two, sahapsat, jol-lhah', are non-ceremonial betrothal forms akin to elopement. The first of these forms involves the following elements.
#The negotiation of a bride-price between the parents of the groom and the parents of the bride (however one must note that the concept of 'bride price' mentioned here is very different from the Hindu concept of the 'dowry system') #The establishment of a date for the departure of the bride from her parents' house to that of her husband #The sending (by the groom) of strong young men to bring the bride to her new home; ceremonial feasting and wrestling then followed #The triumphant return of the groom's representatives with the bride
The 'sahapsat' marriage form contains only the marital negotiations between families. The "jol-lhah" marriage is resorted to in the case of a pregnancy resulting from premarital relationships. In this case, a bride-price is usually agreed upon before the cohabitation process, which begins immediately when the pregnancy is discovered. The "kijam mang" is a marital arrangement that results from the union of two parties Without the consent of the parents of either bride, groom, or both by eloping. The bride-price is settled at some point after the union takes place. Post-marital residence is patrilocal . Inheritance is exclusively through the male line, i.e., eldest son. Thadou women are the chief agents of socialisation among the Thadou society. Children are permitted a great degree of independence once they learn to walk. Little structured education is provided by the parents, thereby leaving the Thadou child to learn through experiential means.
==Literature== Dr. G.C. Crozier along with his wife Mrs M.B. Crozier and [[Pu Ngulhao Thomsong]] worked in full co-operation to translate the Bible especially in Thadou after obtaining permission from the British and Foreign Bible Society. Pu Ngulhao earlier works included, 1) Pathen La- 1922 2) Thukidong leh Kidonbut – 1924 3)Pathen Thu – 1925 4) [[John the Apostle|John]] Sut Kipana Thupha- 1925 5) Lung Phatvet- 1930, 6) [[Epistle to the Romans|Rome]] Mite Henga [[Paul the Apostle|Paul]] Lekha Thot – 1933.
The first edition of "Lekha bul:Thadou Kuki first primer" was written by Pu Ngulhao Thomsong in 1927
Pu Longkhobel Kilong (1922) and was another native scholar of this period.
==References== {{Reflist}}
===Other sources=== *Shaw, William. 1929. Notes on the Thadou kuki. *Shakespear, J. Part I, London, 1912, The Lushai Kuki Clans. Aizawl : Tribal Research Unit. *Tribal Research Institute. 1994. The Tribes of Mizoram. (A Dissertation) Aizawl: Tribal Research Institute, Directorate of Art and Culture. *The Socio-Economics Of Linguistic Identity A Case Study In The Lushai Hills. Satarupa Dattamajumdar, Ph.D. *Lieut. R. Stewart in the Journal of the Asiatic Society of Bengal (1857). entitled "A slight notice of the Grammar of Thadou or New Kookie language."
==External links== {{Kuki-Chin-Mizo tribes}} {{Scheduled tribes of India}} [[Category:Kuki tribes]] [[Category:Ethnic groups in India]] [[Category:Ethnic groups in Myanmar]] [[Category:Ethnic groups in Bangladesh]] [[Category:Scheduled Tribes of Manipur]]

The '''Tokitsukaze stable hazing scandal''' occurred in Japan on June 26, 2007, when {{nihongo|'''Takashi Saito'''|斉藤 俊|''Saitō Takashi''}}, a seventeen-year-old junior [[sumo wrestler]] who fought under the ''[[shikona]]'' of '''Tokitaizan''', collapsed and died after a training session at [[Tokitsukaze stable]]'s lodgings in [[Inuyama]], [[Aichi Prefecture]], [[Japan]]. It emerged that he was beaten with a [[beer bottle]] and a metal [[baseball bat]] at the direction of his trainer.<ref>[https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2008/03/09/AR2008030901742.html Brutal Beating Death Brings Sumo's Dark Side to Light], ''[[The Washington Post]]'', March 10, 2008.</ref> Saito's cause of death had been reported as [[heart failure]], but his father insisted on an [[autopsy]], which revealed the abuse.
Saito's stable master, [[Futatsuryū Jun'ichi|Jun'ichi Yamamoto]], admitted to beating the 17-year-old novice, who had only been in sumo for three months, and ordering other sumo wrestlers to beat him, due to Saito's "vague attitude" towards the sport. It was also reported that Saito had run away from the stable on a number of occasions. Yamamoto was expelled by the [[Japan Sumo Association]]. Yamamoto and three wrestlers from the stable were arrested in February 2008 and were charged with [[manslaughter]]. In May [[2009 in sumo|2009]] Yamamoto was sentenced to six years in prison.<ref>{{cite web|title=Former stable master gets six years for young wrestler's hazing death|publisher=[[Japan Times]]|url=http://www.japantimes.co.jp/cgi-bin/nn20090530a3.html|date=30 May 2009|accessdate=1 June 2009}}</ref> The incident brought substantial political pressure to the governance of the sport in Japan.
Partly as a result of the Saito case, the [[Diet of Japan]] drafted a law promoting cause-of-death investigations which was enacted in 2012.<ref name="shimbun180123">{{cite web|url=http://www.asahi.com/ajw/articles/AJ201801230003.html|title=Police heighten forensics after botching death of sumo wrestler|date=23 January 2018|publisher=''Asahi Shimbun''|accessdate=23 January 2018}}</ref> A separate law in 2013 gave discretion to local police chiefs to allow autopsies even in cases where there were apparently few signs of foul play.<ref name="shimbun180123"/>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://sumodb.sumogames.de/Rikishi.aspx?shikona=tokitaizan Tokitaizan Takashi]
