page.title: Unsung: A History of Women in American Music

revision.text:
{{Infobox book | name = Unsung: A History of Women in American Music | author = [[Christine Ammer]] | image = Unsung A History of Women in American Music.jpg | caption = | alt = | editor = | title_orig = | translator = | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = United States | language = English | series =[[Contributions in Women's Studies]] no. 14 | subject = [[Women in music]] | publisher = [[Greenwood Press]], Amadeus Press | pub_date = 1980, 2001 | english_pub_date = | media_type = Print | pages =317, 382 | isbn = 9780313229091 | oclc = 5289380 | dewey = | congress = | preceded_by = | followed_by = }} '''''Unsung: A History of Women in American Music''''' is a [[non-fiction]] book written by [[Christina Ammer]] about the subject of [[women in music]] and was first published in 1980 with a second edition published in 2001. The book covers approximately 200 years of [[United States|American]] women's involvement in music.<ref>{{Cite journal|url = http://www.publishersweekly.com/pw/print/20010122/30891-spring-2001-book-list.html|title = Spring 2001 Book List|last = Riippa|first = Laurele|date = 22 January 2001|journal = Publishers Weekly|doi = |pmid = |access-date = 25 January 2016|volume = 247|issue = 4}}</ref> ''Unsung'' has become a "standard text" for the subject of American women in music.<ref>{{Cite journal|url = https://muse.jhu.edu/journals/music_and_letters/v087/87.1garnett.html|title = New Historical Anthology of Music by Women|last = Garnett|first = Liz|date = 2006|journal = Music & Letters|doi = |pmid = |access-date = 25 January 2016|subscription = yes|via = Project MUSE|volume = 87|issue = 1|pages = 167–171}}</ref>
''Unsung'' covers many aspects of women in music with the exception of singers, due to the author's assertion that they do not experience the same level of [[Sexism|gender discrimination]] as other endeavors women pursue in music, such as [[conducting]] or composing.<ref name=":2" /> ''Unsung'' discusses this sexism that many women face during their musical careers, especially in the world of [[classical music]] and [[academia]].<ref name=":3">{{Cite journal|url = http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=hft&AN=510077034&site=ehost-live|title = Gendering Musical Modernism|last = Thomson|first = Andrew|date = 15 October 2001|journal = Musical Times|doi = |pmid = |access-date = 25 January 2016|pages = 62–63|volume = 142|issue = 1876|via = EBSCO|subscription = yes}}</ref>
== First edition == Ammer wrote the first edition of ''Unsung'' because there was a lack of material about women in music at the time.<ref name=":3" /> When ''Unsung'' was first published in 1980 it was considered "a pioneering volume at a time when women in music was a fledgling area located at the margins of [[musicology]]," according to ''[[Music & Letters]]''.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|url = http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=a9h&AN=7307004&site=ehost-live|title = Unsung (Book)|last = Citron|first = Marcia|date = August 2002|journal = Music & Letters|doi = |pmid = |access-date = 25 January 2016|volume = 83|issue = 3|via = EBSCO|subscription = yes}}</ref> Not only did the first edition of ''Unsung'' bring attention to women's roles in music, but also helped music from the [[United States]] gain "scholarly legitimacy."<ref name=":0" /> ''[[Library Journal]]'' praised the first addition for its accessible prose and for the information about living composers "available nowhere else."<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|url = http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=lfh&AN=5747451&site=ehost-live|title = Unsung (Book Review)|last = Newlin|first = Dika|date = April 1980|journal = Library Journal|doi = |pmid = |access-date = 25 January 2016|page = 860|volume = 105|issue = 7|subscription = yes|via = EBSCO}}</ref>
== Second edition == The second edition contains much of the same work as the original, with the additions of women's contributions to [[jazz]] and [[popular music]].<ref name=":0" /> Other changes include the additions of women involved in [[electronic music]], music for film, [[performance art]], and "international fusion."<ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|url = http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=lfh&AN=4086052&site=ehost-live|title = Unsung (Book Review)|last = Dopp|first = Bonnie Jo|date = 15 February 2001|journal = Library Journal|doi = |pmid = |access-date = 25 January 2016|volume = 126|issue = 3|page = 169|via = EBSCO|subscription = yes}}</ref>
== Criticism == ''Library Journal'' felt that the title was somewhat negative, saying that "many of these fine musicians have been widely acclaimed."<ref name=":1" />

<!--- Categories ---> [[Category:Articles created via the Article Wizard]] [[Category:Books about musicians]] [[Category:Feminist books]] [[Category:Women's history]] [[Category:Books about women]]

{{EngvarB|date=September 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2015}} {{Infobox women |image = Bali – Kuta (2692353814).jpg |caption = Indonesian women often run small business to support their family, such as traders in marketplace or as [[Hawker (trade)|street vendors]]. |gii = 0.494 (2012) |gii_rank = 106th |matdeath = 220 (2010) |womparl = 18.2% (2012) |femed = 48.9% (2012) |womlab = 51.2% (2011) | ggg = 0.6613 (2013) | ggg_rank = 95th | ggg_ref = <ref name="ggr">{{cite web|title=The Global Gender Gap Report 2013|url=http://www3.weforum.org/docs/WEF_GenderGap_Report_2013.pdf#page=20|publisher=World Economic Forum|pages=12–13}}</ref> }}
The roles of '''women in Indonesia''' today are being affected by many factors, including increased modernisation, globalisation, improved education and advances in technology. Many [[Indonesia]]n women choose to reside in cities instead of staying in townships to perform agricultural work because of personal, professional, and family-related necessities, and economic requirements. These women are moving away from the traditional dictates of [[Culture of Indonesia|Indonesian culture]], wherein women act simply and solely as wives and mothers. At present, the women of Indonesia are also venturing actively into the realm of national development, and working as active members of [[List of women's organizations|organisations]] that focus and act on [[feminism|women's issues]] and concerns.<ref>{{cite web |last=Ingham |first=Xylia |url=http://www.acicis.murdoch.edu.au/hi/women.html |title=Career Women in Indonesia: Obstacles Faced, and Prospects for Change |publisher=Australian Consortium for 'In-Country' Indonesian Studies|year=2005 |accessdate=6 May 2011}}</ref><ref name=TWNS/>
== History == [[File:Parvati Majapahit 2.JPG|thumb|left|upright|[[Tribhuwana Wijayatunggadewi|Tribhuwanottunggadewi]], queen of [[Majapahit]], portrayed as [[Parvati]].]] In Indonesian society, women performed vital roles both within and outside the family. In rural [[Native Indonesian|native]] society, certain positions, such as ''dukun beranak'' (traditional [[midwife]]), [[Traditional medicine|traditional healer]], ritualist, and [[Shamanism|shaman]], are often held by women. Despite their roles seeming to being reduced, if not rather confined, after the adoption of somewhat [[Patriarchy|patriarchal]] cultures of [[Hinduism in Indonesia|Hinduism]], [[Buddhism in Indonesia|Buddhism]], [[Islam in Indonesia|Islam]], and [[Christianity in Indonesia|Christianity]], women still hold important positions, especially within families.
In [[Balinese people|Balinese]] society, women traditionally play important roles, especially concerning family and economic life. Despite traditional values that hold Balinese women responsible for fostering balance and harmony within families and producing high-quality offspring, in a fast changing society, their economic role has grown.<ref>{{cite journal | title = Balinese Women in a Changing Society | author = Luh Ketut Suryani | url = http://guilfordjournals.com/doi/abs/10.1521/jaap.32.1.213.28335}}</ref> It is common for Balinese women to pursue economic activities outside of their household; thus, Balinese traditional marketplaces are filled with women running businesses.
The [[Minangkabau people|Minangkabaus]] are known as one of the few traditional societies that apply [[Matriarchy|matriarchal]] and [[matrilineal]] culture, where property and family names are inherited from mother to daughter, and husbands are considered as "guests" in their wives' household.<ref name="BBC-Minangkabau">{{cite news | title = World’s largest matrilineal society | author = Rathina Sankari | date = 22 September 2016 | work = BBC | url = http://www.bbc.com/travel/story/20160916-worlds-largest-matrilineal-society}}</ref> The Minangkabau culture also recognizes a prominent historic female figure, [[Dara Jingga|Bundo Kanduang]], the matriarch of Minangkabau society. Today, Bundo Kanduang refers to the traditional institution consisting of female elders revered in [[adat]] (tradition) of Minangkabau society.<ref>{{cite news | title = Perempuan Minangkabau | newspaper = Harian Haluan | date = 23 January 2016 | url = http://harianhaluan.com/news/detail/47622/perempuan-minangkabau}}</ref>
In [[History of Indonesia|Indonesian history]], there are records of some prominent women that held and exercised considerable power and influences within their society, despite usually reserved only for elite ruling class. Among others are [[Shima (queen)|Queen Shima]] of [[Kalingga Kingdom]] (c. 7th century), [[Pramodhawardhani]] of [[Medang Kingdom]] (c. 9th century), [[Isyana Tunggawijaya]] of Medang [[Isyana dynasty]] (c. 10th century), [[Mahendradatta]] of [[Bali Kingdom|Bali]] (c. 10th century), [[Ken Dedes]] of [[Singhasari]] (c. 13th century), also queens of [[Majapahit]] (c. 13th-15th century); [[Gayatri Rajapatni]], [[Tribhuwana Wijayatunggadewi]] and [[Suhita]]. Later after the coming of Islam in Java, [[Ratu Kalinyamat]] of Jepara also a notable female leader. [[Aceh Sultanate|Sultanate of Aceh]] also recorded several [[Sultana (title)|sultanahs]] ever ruled the Aceh sultanate. Indonesian Republic recognized several historic [[National Hero of Indonesia|national heroines]] that fought against Dutch colonialism; among others are [[Nyi Ageng Serang]], [[Martha Christina Tiahahu]], [[Cut Nyak Dhien]] and [[Cut Nyak Meutia]]. [[File:COLLECTIE TROPENMUSEUM De Kartinischool een lagere school voor meisjes te Jakarta Java TMnr 10002290.jpg|thumb|right|Kartini school in early 20th century.]] The [[Women's rights|women's emancipation]] movement was started in late 19th century colonial [[Dutch East Indies]], when a handful of upperclass native woman advocated for women's rights and education for women. These women's right pioneers are [[Kartini]] of Jepara and [[Dewi Sartika]] of Bandung, both of them established school for girls, and has been recognized as the national heroine of Indonesia.<ref name="Women in Indonesia">{{cite book | title = Women in Indonesia: Gender, Equity and Development, Volume 8 dari Indonesia assessment series | author1 = Kathryn May Robinson | author2= Sharon Bessell | publisher = Institute of Southeast Asian Studies | year = 2002 | isbn = 9789812301581 | url = https://books.google.co.id/books?id=jUOYUTPXkhwC&dq=Women+in+Indonesia&hl=id&source=gbs_navlinks_s}}</ref>{{rp|page=5}}
[[Women's suffrage]] was never an issue in Indonesia, since [[Indonesian legislative election, 1955|its first election in 1955]] Indonesia held that women has equal rights with men in politics, although in practice politics is still a male-dominated realm. In 2001, [[Megawati Sukarnoputri]]—then serving as Vice President—became the first female president of Indonesia after the removal of President [[Abdurrahman Wahid]].<ref name="Women in Indonesia"/>{{rp|page=1}}
== Women's rights == {{Women in society sidebar}} Indonesia signed the [[Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women]] in 1980 and ratified it in 1984.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.academia.edu/4517841/The_Implementation_of_CEDAW_Related_to_Women_s_Quota_in_Indonesian_Parliament|title=The Implementation of CEDAW Related to Women’s Quota in Indonesian Parliament|last=Zahra|first=Tri Inaya|work=Academia.edu|accessdate=10 December 2016}}</ref>
=== National law and sharia === The Indonesian National Commission on Violence Against Women noted that more regulations that discriminate against women are being adopted throughout the country than are being repealed. <ref name="loc.gov">{{cite web|url=https://www.loc.gov/law/foreign-news/article/indonesia-commission-finds-many-laws-that-discriminate-against-women/|title=Indonesia: Commission Finds Many Laws that Discriminate Against Women |work= Global Legal Monitor|date=19 September 2012|publisher=Library of Congress}} {{PD-notice}}</ref> In 2012, the Commission noted 282 bylaws in various jurisdictions across Indonesia that it deemed discriminatory, compared with 154 such instruments in 2009.<ref name="loc.gov"/> There are 96 that impose criminal sanctions on women through regulations on prostitution and pornography, 60 that contain dress codes and religious standards, and 38 that place restrictions on women’s mobility.<ref name="loc.gov"/> Although such bylaws can be found in 28 Indonesian provinces, the six provinces in which they are largely concentrated are East Java, South Kalimantan, South Sulawesi, West Java, West Nusa Tenggara, and West Sumatra.<ref name="loc.gov"/>
In many parts of Indonesia, local laws compelling women and girls to wear the [[hijab]] are increasingly in place in schools, government offices and public spaces.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://america.aljazeera.com/opinions/2014/11/indonesia-women-srightsvirginitytestsfemalepoliceofficers.html|title=OPINION: Indonesian women’s rights under siege|last=Harsono|first=Andreas|work=Al Jazeera America|date=25 November 2014|accessdate=10 December 2016}}</ref> Aceh province has implemented [[Sharia]] law in full.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/indonesian-woman-lashed-standing-too-close-her-boyfriend-violation-sharia-law-1589065|title=Indonesian woman lashed for standing too close to her boyfriend in violation of Sharia law|first=Ludovica|last=Iaccino|date=31 October 2016|work=International Business Times|accessdate=10 December 2016}}</ref> In Aceh, all Muslim women must wear the traditional head covering known as hijab; fraternising with the opposite sex outside marriage is banned.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.smh.com.au/world/ban-on-outdoor-music-concerts-in-west-aceh-due-to-sharia-law-20160406-gnzvna.html|title=Ban on outdoor music concerts in West Aceh due to Sharia law|first=Jewel|last=Topsfield|date=7 April 2016|work=The Sydney Morning Herald|accessdate=10 December 2016}}</ref>
=== Sexual crime and harassment === More than 90 percent of [[rape]] cases in Indonesia go unreported, victims fear being blamed.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.trust.org/item/20160725143529-udc98|title=Over 90 percent rape cases go unreported in Indonesia - poll|author=Beh Lih Yi|editor-last=Whiting|editor-first=Alex|date=25 July 2016|publisher=Thomson Reuters Foundation|accessdate=10 December 2016}}</ref>
==== Women-only transport ==== [[File:KRL Jabotabek 8500 Gambir 20111126.JPG|thumb|right|A women-only car at the front of a KRL Jabotabek commuter train]] An Indonesian railway company, ''[[Kereta Api Indonesia|PT Kereta Api]]'', introduced [[Women-only passenger car|women-only carriages]] on some [[KA Commuter Jabodetabek|KRL Jabotabek]] commuter trains in the [[Jabodetabek|Jakarta metropolitan area]] from August 2010 in response to many reports of sexual harassment in public places, including commuter trains and buses. <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thejakartaglobe.com/home/indonesia-railway-company-launches-women-only-carriages/391784|title=Indonesia Railway Company Launches Women-Only Carriages|author=|date=|website=thejakartaglobe.com}}</ref>
The women-only carriages on commuter trains are usually denoted by large pink or purple stickers, which read "''Kereta Khusus Wanita''", and are located at each end of the train. This kind of carriage was previously only able to be found on air-conditioned EMUs, but a number of recently repaired non-air conditioned EMUs have also been equipped with the women-only carriage stickers.
Recently, ''PT Kereta Api'' launched a special women-only train (the train itself uses an ex-[[Tokyo Metro 6000 series]] EMU, set number 6107F), which intended as further protection for female passengers from sexual harassment. To give difference from standard EMUs (which only provides women-only carriages on each end of the train), the women-only train had all of its cars decorated with large "''Kereta Khusus Wanita''" stickers coloured purple or pink. Since 1 October 2012, ''PT Kereta Api Indonesia'' (Persero) Commuter Jabodetabek launch the women-only trains.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://charleskkb.blogspot.com/2012/10/operasi-perdana-rangkaian-khusus-wanita.html|title=ジャボデタベク電気鉄道センター: Operasi Perdana Rangkaian Khusus Wanita - 女性専用編成最初運転|first=Charles|last=Yulianto|date=1 October 2012|website=charleskkb.blogspot.com}}</ref> This practice ended in May 2013 after reports found that mixed-use cars were overcrowded during rush hour while women's only cars were underutilized.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.marieclaire.co.uk/news/world/542689/indonesian-women-only-trains-are-scrapped.html|title=What Real Women Think Of Women-Only Train Carriages|author=|date=24 August 2017|website=marieclaire.co.uk}}</ref>
== Marriage and family life == [[File:Minangkabau wedding 2.jpg|thumb|right|Minangkabau wedding, the [[Minangkabau people|Minangs]] are one of the few ethnic groups that practice [[matrilineality]].]] [[Dowry]] is seldom to never practiced in [[Indonesian culture]], yet [[bride price]] is practiced by certain ethnic groups. For example, the ''uang panai'' bride price in [[Bugis]] culture. The more prominent the education, career, beauty, social and economic strata, or noble background of the bride, the more expensive the ''uang panai'' should be paid.<ref>{{cite news | title = "Uang Panai", Tanda Penghargaan untuk Meminang Gadis Bugis-Makassar | author = Hendra Cipto | work = Kompas.com | date = 13 March 2017 | url = http://regional.kompas.com/read/2017/03/13/08532951/.uang.panai.tanda.penghargaan.untuk.meminang.gadis.bugis-makassar | language = Indonesian}}</ref> In Minangkabau matrilineal culture, the payment of the bride price—or more correctly addressed as the "groom price", is given to the groom's parents, as the husband is entering his newly wed wife's household. The more prominent the education and career of the groom, the more expensive the groom price should be paid. The custom is called ''bajapuik'' or ''uang japuik'', although historically a widespread practice in Minangkabau land, today only people of [[Padang Pariaman Regency|Pariaman]] that persistently practice this custom.<ref>{{cite web | title = Uang Japuik, Tradisi Unik 'Beli' Laki-laki dari Ranah Minang | work = Otonomi.co.id | language = Indonesian | url = https://www.otonomi.co.id/ragam/uang-japuik-tradisi-unik-beli-laki-laki-dari-ranah-minang-1701170.html }}</ref> The more commonly prevailing national culture is the ''mas kawin'' (lit. "marriage gold") or ''mahar'' which refer to a gift provided by the groom to be given to the bride. It may contain a sum of money or gold, sometimes because of the adoption of Islamic culture, also include or replaced by symbolic religious items such as ''seperangkat alat sholat'' (Islamic praying equipment).<ref>{{cite news | date = 26 July 2011 | title = Mahar dengan Seperangkat Alat Sholat | newspaper = Republika | url = http://www.republika.co.id/berita/konsultasi/ustadz-menjawab/11/07/26/lox8ko-mahar-dengan-seperangkat-alat-sholat | language = Indonesian }}</ref>
As many other developing countries, a high [[fertility rate]] is a major problem facing the country.<ref name="futuredirections1">{{cite web|url=http://www.futuredirections.org.au/publication/social-and-demographic-issues-in-indonesia/|title=Social and Demographic Issues in Indonesia – Future Directions International|date=27 August 2015|publisher=}}</ref><ref>http://www.copenhagenconsensus.com/sites/default/files/indonesia_packet_population.pdf</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ic.keio.ac.jp/en/download/jjwbgsp/2007/2_Indonesia.pdf|title=Indonesia<!-- Bot generated title -->|author=|date=|website=keio.ac.jp}}</ref> Traditionally, Indonesian society has viewed children as the source of [[Wealth|fortune]].<ref name="futuredirections1"/> A local saying that more children equated to more fortune and it was widely believed that the use of contraceptives contravened religious and moral values.<ref>http://jurnal.ugm.ac.id/jurnal-humaniora/article/download/1808/1625</ref><ref>http://www.oxis.org/m-z/idrus-2004.pdf</ref> This contributed to a very high fertility rate. Recognising that high fertility was a major factor in creating widespread poverty.<ref name=autogenerated1>https://www.adb.org/sites/default/files/publication/28140/asra02.pdf</ref> Child marriage is also sustained by traditional norms.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.research.leiden.edu/research-profiles/amt/news/8-june2015.html|title=9–10 June: Child Marriage, Sexual Moralities and the Politics of Decentralization in Indonesia – News – Research|publisher=Universiteit Leiden|accessdate=10 December 2016}}</ref>
[[Child marriage]] is common.<ref name="auto">{{cite web|url=http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2016/07/20/child-marriage-a-serious-problem-in-indonesia.html|title=Child marriage a serious problem in Indonesia|work=The Jakarta Post|date=20 July 2016|accessdate=10 December 2016}}</ref> It is among the triggering factors of diseases in women such as cervical cancer.<ref name="auto"/> Child marriage is sustained by traditional norms.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.research.leiden.edu/research-profiles/amt/news/8-june2015.html|title=9-10 June: Child Marriage, Sexual Moralities and the Politics of Decentralization in Indonesia - News - Research|publisher=Universiteit Leiden|accessdate=10 December 2016}}</ref>
== Health and welfare == [[File:COLLECTIE TROPENMUSEUM In juni 1950 organiseerde de leiding van de KOWANI (Kongres Wanita Indonesia) in Djakarta een congres dat door alle afdelingen in Indonesië werd bijgewoond TMnr 10000216.jpg|thumb|left|President [[Sukarno]] with leaders of the Indonesian Women's Congress in June 1950.]]
Many pregnant women in Indonesia do not have the financial capability to pay for hospital deliveries and [[Childbirth|birthing]] by [[Caesarean section]], because of disproportionate salaries and medical expenses. Thus, these women require the support and assistance of "[[home birth|birth]] sanctuaries" that provide "free prenatal care, birthing services and medical aid", such as the ''Yayasan Bumi Sehat'' (Healthy Mother Earth Foundation) health clinics established by [[Robin Lim]], an American midwife, in 2003. Such 24-hour nativity havens, mostly located in [[Bali]] and [[Aceh]], help Indonesian women to escape the common practice of private hospitals in Indonesia that entails detaining newborn infants until medical bills are fully remunerated by the birth mothers.<ref>{{cite web |last=Ruffins|first=Ebonne|url=http://www.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/asiapcf/03/10/cnnheroes.lim.midwife/index.html |title=CNN Heroes: 'Mother Robin' delivers for poor women in Indonesia |publisher=[[CNN]] |date=10 March 2011 |access-date=6 May 2011}}</ref>
Nonetheless, the economy now seems to be improving (high GDP growth in 2012 as high as 6.2%)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.worldbank.org/en/country/indonesia|title=Indonesia|author=|date=|website=worldbank.org}}</ref> and some programs had been done by the government to help promote the health and welfare of women and child. A ministry that especially concerns in the field had been established for a long time since the regime of the late President [[Suharto]] during the [[New Order (Indonesia)|New Order]].<ref>http://www.indonesia.go.id/in/kementerian/kementerian/kementerian-negara-pemberdayaan-perempuan-dan-perlindungan-anak/1647-profile/274-kementerian-pemberdayaan-perempuan-dan-perlindungan-anak</ref>
== Employment == [[File:Ubud Bali Indonesia The Market.jpg|thumb|In a traditional market, women commonly run businesses.]] In Indonesian culture, it is a social norm for husbands to economically provides for his wife and the whole family. Which means husband's earnings is expected to be given to the wife monthly and to be managed by her for family spending and savings. However, it is normal for women to pursue economic activity. For example, ''[[warung]]'', a small scale family-owned store, is often run equally by men or women. In most parts of the country, Indonesian women traditionally enjoyed a degree of social and economic freedom. To support their family's economy, Indonesian women are involved in economic activities outside of their households, although mostly informal small-scale business. It is common to find women run businesses in traditional Indonesian marketplaces.
After a surge of foreign [[Multinational corporation|multinational investors]] began investing in Indonesia during the 1970s, many Indonesian women became the "prime workforce" and a source of [[Sweatshop|cheap labourers]] in manufacturing businesses.<ref name=TWNS>{{cite web |last=Ahmad |first=Abdul Razak |url=http://www.twnside.org.sg/title/abdul-cn.htm |title=Redefining the role of women in Indonesia|date=29 December 1998 |work=[[New Straits Times]] |publisher=Third World Network |accessdate=6 May 2011}}</ref> In the 1990s, some women in Indonesia, including adolescents and the homeless, resorted to engage in employment as [[sex worker]]s and [[maid|housemaids]] due to financial hardship. Some of the women who were forced into such work [[Indonesian migrant worker|opted to go abroad]], into countries such as [[Saudi Arabia]], [[Malaysia]], [[Hong Kong]], and [[Taiwan]]. Some have since become victims of torture, sexual abuse, murder, illegal detention, rape, sodomy, and other forms of sexual assault. Health-wise, as a consequence of becoming prostituted by human traffickers, some have contracted [[HIV/AIDS]] and other [[Sexually transmitted infection|sexually transmitted diseases]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.catwinternational.org/factbook/Indonesia.php |title=Indonesia |publisher=Coalition Against Trafficking in Women |accessdate=6 May 2011}}</ref>
[[File:Sri Mulyani @ 40 jaar NCDO.jpg|thumb|left|[[Sri Mulyani Indrawati]], an influential Indonesian economist, currently Minister of Finance.]]
Indonesia is among the [[List of elected and appointed female heads of state and government|countries which have had a female president]]; [[Megawati Sukarnoputri]] served as president of Indonesia from 2001 to 2004. In 2012, 18% of national parliament representatives were held by women.<ref name="Bachelet">{{cite web|last=Bachelet|first=Michelle|title=Women are integral part of Indonesian success|url=http://www.unwomen.org/en/news/stories/2012/12/women-are-integral-part-of-indonesian-success/|publisher=UN Women|accessdate=18 November 2013}}</ref> [[Tri Rismaharini]] is one example of the rising numbers of female leaders throughout Indonesia. More and more women are becoming scholars. The ratio of girls to boys in primary and secondary schools is also even as of 2013.<ref>{{cite web|title=Ratio of girls to boys in primary and secondary education (%) |url=http://data.worldbank.org|publisher=The World Bank|accessdate=18 November 2013}}</ref>
More scholarships awarded by the Indonesian government (and some other institutions other than the government) were given to women, and resulted in higher achievement in their later life.{{citation needed|date=November 2013}} In most major cities like Jakarta and Surabaya, the educated female workforce tends to postpone the marital age and girls who finish secondary school are six times less likely to marry early.<ref name="Bachelet"/>
Indonesian women could be making considerable shifts to national employment - women currently hold 33% of non-agricultural employment as they also work in the prestigious and traditionally male-dominated field such as architecture, medicine, and engineering.<ref>{{cite web|title=Share of women employed in the nonagricultural sector (% of total nonagricultural employment)|url=http://data.worldbank.org|publisher=The World Bank|accessdate=18 November 2013}}</ref> Indonesian women has pursued various line of works and some has excel in their career. Prominent women figure including economists such as [[Sri Mulyani Indrawati]] and [[Mari Elka Pangestu]], Olympic gold medalist sportswomen such as [[Susi Susanti]] and [[Liliyana Natsir]], to activists such as [[Butet Manurung]] and [[Yenny Wahid]]. [[File:Susi Pudjiastuti.jpg|thumb|upright|[[Susi Pudjiastuti]], a prominent businesswoman and the Maritime and Fisheries Minister in President Joko Widodo administration.]] During the administration of President [[Joko Widodo]], Indonesia had 26 percent female representation among state [[Minister (government)|ministers]], the highest among the 10 [[List of countries by population (United Nations)|most populous countries]].{{fact|date=April 2018}} Indonesia has increasingly put women in senior roles in the government, business and finance. Prominence officials include Finance Minister [[Sri Mulyani Indrawati]], Foreign Minister [[Retno Marsudi]], and Maritime and Fisheries Minister [[Susi Pudjiastuti]], are female ministers in Joko Widodo administration. Also Rosmaya Hadi as [[Bank Indonesia]]'s deputy governor.<ref>{{cite news | title = Indonesia, world's biggest Muslim country, puts more women into senior roles | date = 25 July 2017 | newspaper = The Straits Times | url = http://www.straitstimes.com/asia/se-asia/indonesia-worlds-biggest-muslim-country-puts-more-women-into-senior-roles}}</ref>

{{Primary sources|date=January 2009}} '''World Climate Report''', a newsletter edited by [[Patrick Michaels]], was produced by the [[Greening Earth Society]], a non-profit organization created by the [[Western Fuels Association]]. Early editions were paper based; it was then transferred to a web-only format, having ceased publication as a physically based report with Volume 8 in 2002. It continues to exist in [[blog]] form at [http://www.worldclimatereport.com www.worldclimatereport.com], although the website itself has not been updated since late 2012. World Climate Report presents a scientific skeptical view of populist [[human impact on the environment|anthropogenic]]-driven mass global climate change, or as it describes, '[[Global Warming Alarmism]]'. However, it does not reject the concepts of global climate change or [[greenhouse effect|greenhouse theory]] (or other well-established and widely accepted scientific theories or empirical studies),{{cite news |last= World Climate Report |title= Methane Matters |url= http://www.worldclimatereport.com/index.php/2007/04/13/methane-matters/ |work= World Climate Report |date= April 13, 2007 |accessdate= 2007-05-03 |quote= "There is no doubt that fossil fuel burning around the world is causing an increase in atmospheric carbon dioxide ({{CO2}}) concentration, and {{CO2}} remains the number one anthropo-generated greenhouse gas." [and] "[M]ethane is far more powerful as a greenhouse gas than {{CO2}} – the same mass of [[methane]] would warm the earth 23 times more than the same mass of {{CO2}}."}}{{cite news |last= World Climate Report |title= Global Warming: Something New Under the Sun? |url= http://www.worldclimatereport.com/index.php/2005/05/10/global-warming-something-new-under-the-sun/ |work= World Climate Report |date= May 10, 2005 |accessdate= 2007-05-09 |quote= "Before you kill the greenhouse effect, please note that we think this is a lot of hooey. But if you accept these results, that’s where you have to go." [and] "That’s our take, because it’s the only one that seems internally consistent. But, if somehow we are wrong (a rare event), then greenhouse warming is over, as the sensitivity of the earth’s temperature to carbon dioxide has been grossly overestimated. Believe us, we’d like to hope the latter is correct, but we have to call things in the most logical fashion."}} in general attempting to engender itself as giving a well balanced and scientific view of the sources (though often at a contrary expense of its perceived adversaries: the aforementioned alleged 'Global Warming Alarmists').{{cite news |first= Patrick |last= Michaels |title= New Climate for Global Energy Policy |url= http://www.cato.org/pub_display.php?pub_id=7501 |work= [[Cato Institute]] Opinion & Commentary |date= February 6, 2007 |accessdate= 2007-05-03 |quote= In summary, what's not new in today's IPCC report – that humans are warming the planet – will be treated as big news, while what is new – that sea levels are not likely to rise as much as previously predicted – will be ignored, at least by everyone except the extremist fringe.}} WCR says of itself: : ''World Climate Report, a concise, hard-hitting and scientifically correct response to the global change reports which gain attention in the literature and popular press. As the nation's leading publication in this realm, World Climate Report is exhaustively researched, impeccably referenced, and always timely. This popular biweekly newsletter points out the weaknesses and outright fallacies in the science that is being touted as "proof" of disastrous warming. It's the perfect antidote against those who argue for proposed changes to the [[Rio Climate Treaty]], such as the [[Kyoto Protocol]], which are aimed at limiting carbon emissions from the [[United States]] ... World Climate Report has become the definitive and unimpeachable source for what ''nature'' now calls the “mainstream skeptic” point of view.'' [http://www.worldclimatereport.com/index.php/about-us/]. In addition to Patrick Michaels (chief editor), the staff is listed as [[Robert Balling|Robert C. Balling, Jr]] (contributing editor), [[Robert E. Davis (climatologist)|Robert Davis]] (contributing editor), and [[Paul Knappenberger]] (Administrator). [[New Hope Environmental Services]], an advocacy science consulting firm, claims WCR as its biweekly newsletter. ==References== * WCR cited by the Space Science and Engineering Center of the University of Wisconsin-Madison: ''In the News: a monthly newsletter'', "[http://www.ssec.wisc.edu/media/april2007.html#data_imagery Data and Imagery]," April 2007. * [http://ff.org/ Frontiers of Freedom]'s [http://ff.org/centers/csspp/misc/index.html Center for Science and Public Policy] produced a document entitled "[http://ff.org/centers/csspp/pdf/CSPP-climatechangeissuesexpanded2005.pdf Recent Research in Climate Change Issues]" in 2005, compiled from numerous WCR articles.
